  • Zhimu (Anemarrhenae Rhizoma) - 2 qian
  • Huanglian (Coptidis Rhizoma) - 2 qian

Preparation: Grind into powder the size of a soybean, add 3 cups of water, boil down to 1 cup, take warm on an empty stomach, and follow with a nourishing meal.

Preparation: Add 3 large cups of water, boil down to 1 cup, take warm before meals. Avoid alcohol, damp food, and sexual activity.

Pang Cong San: [from "He Ji"] Treats men and women with spleen and stomach deficiency and cold, attacking the heart and abdomen causing pain in the ribs, chest tightness, and back pain that extends to the neck, loss of appetite, occasional vomiting, cholera-like cramping, abdominal cold diarrhea, bladder qi stabbing the small intestine, and swelling pain in the outer kidney; also treats women's blood and qi attacks, symptoms and lumps that are hard, discharge of red and white, possible chills and fever, before and after childbirth, continuous abnormal bleeding, abdominal pain, and all signs of deficiency and cold.
Ingredients: Yan Hu Suo 3 taels, Cang Zhu soaked overnight (1 tael), roasted Licorice (half a pound), Bai Fu Ling, Pungent Zhu, San Ling prepared (6 taels each), Ding Pi, Suo Sha Ren, Betel Nut (4 taels each), Cinnamon, and dried Ginger prepared (2 taels each).
Pound and sieve into powder. Take 2 taels with 1 cup of water, add a stalk of green onion, and simmer until reduced to 70%, take warm before meals.

Peach kernel soup: Soak the peach kernels, remove the skins and尖端, and lightly roast the bran until slightly yellow. One tael each of bitter neem seeds, fragrant seeds, and myrrh. Grind them into a fine powder. Take two qian before meals, mixed with hot wine.

Copper green powder: Treats damp sores in men and women, and sores caused by insects. Five qian of gallnut, one qian of white alumen, five fen each of frankincense and copper green, and two and a half fen of light powder. Grind into a powder, first wash with medicinal water, then apply.

Cicada slough powder: Treats sudden swelling of the bladder, often due to sitting or lying in damp areas, or being bothered by insects. Half a tael of cicada slough; use one bowl of water to boil and wash, then warm and wash again. Combine with Wuling powder and Sanxian decoction, taken with lantern leaf.

Liver-clearing and heat-dispelling soup: Treats damp heat in the liver channel, toxins flowing to the bladder channel, leading to kidney abscesses. Tail of gentian mixed and roasted with wine, one qian each of angelica head, plantain seeds, and the following: ze xie, raw earth, peony, huanglian, huangbo, zhi mu, light bamboo leaves, mu tong, and fang feng. Five fen of licorice head. Prepare as a single dose, using two bowls of water to decoct down to eight parts, taken before meals.[154p]

Water Yellow Ointment: Treats the preceding condition.[157p]
Two liang of Coptis, two bowls of water, simmer on mild and strong fires until reduced to one bowl, strain out the dregs. Then, add more water and simmer on low heat until reduced to one wine cup. Add three fen of borneol, three fen of musk, five fen of talcum powder, and one qian of sulfur powder. Grind all of these into a fine powder, mix with the Coptis juice, and use a goose feather to moisten the affected area, and it will have immediate effect.

For a powder remedy to treat the previous symptoms:

All of these should be finely ground and then applied dry to the affected area.

Qingmu Xiang Pill: 200 pills, 7 mallow insects.

Stir-fry them together until slightly fragrant, cover with porcelain, and let cool, removing the mallow insects. Take 50 pills with fennel wine. This is because hernias pertain to the liver; hence, mallow is used to treat wind.

Secret Dispersing Pill of Wu Zhuyu [from "Direct Point Formulas"]
Used to treat hernia and swollen areas of the genitals, or sores that leak yellow fluid.
Soak half Wu Zhuyu in wine and half in vinegar overnight, then dry it.
Add Shan Zhuyu, cinnamon, and Ma Linhua soaked in vinegar and dried.
Then add powdered Muxiang, Heichoutou, stir-fried fennel with salt, fried Yanhusuo, Chuanlian flesh, Qingpi, and Chenpi (remove the white part), and washed and dried Haizhao.
Fry Tao Ren and Bai Jizhi, each five qian.

Mufan Dan [from "Medical Entry", same below]
Used to treat sores on the scrotum that leak fluid, causing severe itching and pain upon scratching.
Use two liang each of oyster powder and yellow lead, and four liang of dried white alum.[162p]
The above text outlines various traditional Chinese medicinal recipes for treating ailments related to hernias, specifically indicating methods for relief from symptoms like swelling and pain due to damp heat.

  1. For itching, the advice is to pinch some medicine and rub it on the itchy area three to four times until it naturally subsides.

  2. Modified Chai Ling Decoction is prescribed for various hernias caused by damp heat leading to swelling and pain. Ingredients include herbs such as Chai Hu, Ze Xie, Ban Xia, Chi Fu Ling, Lychee Seed, Bai Zhu, Zhu Ling, Shan Zha, and Zhi Zi, mixed and brewed, with a substitution of orange seeds if lychee seeds are unavailable.

  3. Shen Sheng Dai Zhen San treats blood-stasis hernia pain and other sharp pains associated with hernias. It includes Frankincense, Myrrh (degreased), Angelica, Bai Zhi, Chuan Xiong, and Yan Qing, ground into powder. It is taken in a specific manner, where one dose is mixed into a cup of good tea and sipped delicately without stirring.

  4. Dang Shan Wan is used for treating Qi hernia. Ingredients include herbs like Feng Zhu, Mu Xiang, and special preparations of various seeds, all mixed into pills that are taken with alcohol.

  5. Qi Hernia Drink also addresses Qi hernia, using preparations like Huang Lian and Wu Zhu Yu boiled and mixed with other ingredients like Gan Cao, Ren Shen, Bai Zhu, Bai Shao, and Chen Pi, brewed with slices of ginger for consumption.[163p]
    San Zhu Wan
    Treats abdominal pain caused by qi stagnation and swelling.
    Two taels each of Shan Zhu Yu, Wu Zhu Yu, and Shi Zhu Yu; one tael of Chuan Lian; one tael and seven qian of po gu zhi, fried; fourteen Gan Mao insects, fried until red, remove the insects; one tael of Hei Chou Tou powder, fried; three qian each of Qing Yan, Qing Pi, and Hui Xiang, fried.
    Grind them into powder, mix with vinegar to make pills the size of a walnut. First chew fifteen peach seeds, then take with warm wine or salt soup, three to five times.

Ju Xiang Yin Zi
Treats injuries from the seven emotions that lead to hernia.
Grind separately Frankincense, Chen Xiang, Bai Dan Xiang, Mu Xiang, Huo Xiang leaves, and Ding Xiang, each eight fen; four fen each of Yan Hu Suo, Jiang Huang, Wu Yao, Jie Geng, Gui Xin, and Gan Cao.
Grind these into a mixture, add three slices of ginger and two jujubes, and decoct in water to take.

Er Xiang Wan
Treats fox hernia with pain appearing intermittently; when hernia pain stops, abdominal lumps cause pain again.
Three taels each of Mu Xiang and Xiang Fu Zi; two taels of Shan Zha meat; one tael each of San Leng and Peng Zhu, boiled with vinegar; one tael each of Shen Ju, Jiang Huang, and Nan Xing; together with Huang Lian and Wu Zhu Yu, fried; five qian each of Luo Bo Zi, Tao Ren, Zhi Zi Ren, and Ju He, fried.
Grind into powder, soak in ginger juice and steam, form into pills the size of a walnut, and take with clear soup, five to seventy pills.[164p]
Tiantai Wuyao San: This formula treats small intestine qi issues. Take ten Chuanlianzi and fourteen pieces of Ba Dou, roast together with wheat until black, then remove the bean and wheat. Add five qian each of Wuyao, muxiang (wood fragrance), foeniculum (fennel), and liangjiang (galanga); three qian of Binglang (betel nut). Grind everything into a fine powder. For each qian, mix with warm wine and take it. If the pain is severe, take with hot wine and ginger.

Jiùmìng Tǒngxīn San: This formula treats small intestine qi pain. Use one liang of Chuanwu and a qian of Qingyan (green salt). Soak in one cup of wine overnight, then peel and roast. Use one liang of Chuanlianzi meat and twenty-one pieces of Ba Dou meat, fry until black, then remove the bean. Add five qian of foeniculum, a pair of shiyan (stone swallow) fired and vinegar-quenched, five pieces of tudu (earth dog), and one qian six fen of mustard seeds. Grind everything into a powder. For every three qian, place in sheep stones, wrap with damp paper, and steam until cooked. At midnight, take half a jin of good wine, chew the stones in salt finely, and swallow with the wine without making a sound. Urination will increase significantly, and the illness will resolve.[165p]
Qulingwan [“Introduction to Medicine”]
For treating small intestine hernia. One pound of fennel, extract natural juice from one pound of fresh ginger, soak overnight until the ginger juice is absorbed by the fennel. Then add two taels of blue salt and stir-fry until red, remove and dry. Grind this mixture into powder, form pills the size of a walnut with wine paste, take thirty to fifty pills with warm wine or rice drink as needed. This medicine can strengthen the spleen and stomach, and the salt helps draw downwards. The ginger juice specifically disperses without harmful laxative effects, and the effects accumulate.

Jiawei Tongxin Drink [“Effective Formulas”]
For treating hot pain in small intestine hernia, with difficulty in urination. One qian each of: Cornelian cherry, Akebia, Cape jasmine, Scutellaria, Forsythia, Bitter orange, Chinaberry, and Licorice. Grind these together to make a paste, then add thirty stalks of lantern wick and five leaves of Plantago, and decoct to take.

Juan Tong Wan [“Direct Reference Formulas”]
For pain in the small intestine and bladder due to Qi. One tael of Corydalis, five qian each of: Chinaberry flesh, stir-fried fennel, and white charcoal powder. Two and a half qian each of: Angelica, Zingiber, green peel, wood fragrance, and myrrh, and seven whole scorpions roasted. Grind this mixture into powder, soak in ginger juice, steam into pills the size of a walnut, and take with wine mixed with burned cotton ash, three to fifty pills as needed.[166p]

Ju He San (from "Dan Xi Xin Fa")
Treats four types of (inguinal) hernia; for chronic cases, use Ju He Wan; for acute cases, use Ju He San.

  • 1.5 qian of tangerine seeds

    Stir-fry each into a coarse powder, make into a paste, and decoct in water for consumption. "Ru Men" states: the tangerine seed alone alleviates pain, Aconitum disperses cold stagnation, gardenia removes damp heat, guiding Aconitum to descend quickly and preventing it from lingering in the stomach, making these remedies highly effective.

    [From "Zhi Zhi Fang"]
    Treats wood kidney and external kidney, bloating, numbness, pain, rigidity, and conditions of tun (testicular) hernia that tends to sag.

Four-Fried Chan Lian Pills

Treats all types of hernias, abdominal swelling and pain, and reduces their size; long-term use will root out the issue.

Use one pound of Chan Lian flesh, divided into four parts:

  • One part with one cup of wheat bran, and forty-nine cockroaches, stir-fried together.
  • One part with one cup of wheat bran, and one tael of Ba Jiao, stir-fried together.
  • One part with one cup of wheat bran, and forty-nine Ba Dou, stir-fried together.
  • One part with one tael of salt, and one cup of fennel, stir-fried together.

Ensure the wheat bran turns yellow; remove other stir-fried ingredients, and use only Chan Lian flesh. Add one tael each of Mu Xiang and Po Gu Zhi, stir-fry until ground, and mix with wine to form pills the size of a jujube. Take fifty pills with salt water, three times a day.

Five-Fried Chan Lian Pills

Treats various hernias.

Use half a pound of Chan Lian flesh.

  • Stir-fry one tael of cockroaches (three pieces).
  • Stir-fry one tael of fennel (three and a half qian).
  • Stir-fry one tael of black (three qian).
  • Stir-fry one tael of Po Gu Zhi (three qian).
  • Stir-fry one tael of radish seeds (one qian).

Remove the stir-fried items, keeping fennel, Po Gu Zhi, and Chan Lian flesh to grind into a powder. Mix with wine to form pills the size of a jujube, and take fifty pills with warm wine.

Ginseng Wine: This is used to treat excessive sexual intercourse, or when the condition after intercourse has not yet stabilized, leading to injury of Qi, severe pain in the tendons, a rolled tongue and bluish lips, contracted testicles, painful abdominal cramps, and an inability to eat or drink.

Oyster Powder

For treating blood hernias and venereal poison.

Ingredients:

  • Wine: 1.5 qian
  • Angelica: 1.5 qian
  • Licorice segments: 1.5 qian
  • Calcined talc: 1.5 qian
  • Calcined oyster: 1.5 qian
  • Rhubarb: 3 qian
  • Five seeds of Mume: 1.5 qian

Preparation:
Grind the ingredients into a powder. Use two cups of water, decoct until reduced to one cup, let it sit overnight, and take it at dawn. In winter, it should be taken warm.

Notes:
If the condition has not erupted, pus, and blood may discharge with stool. Xue Ji commented: This formula is an astringent and cold remedy for stagnation. If there is prolonged neglect of marital matters, constipation, fever, and burning pain, or strong engagement of vital energy, leading to complicated blood intertwining, swelling, pain, and constipation, it is advisable to use this remedy. Conversely, for individuals who are fatigued without significant swelling, having regular bowel habits, or exhibiting reddish and hot urine without purulence, and those whose wounds do not heal, it is better to use the Ten-Ingredient Great Tonifying Decoction. This condition often arises from insufficient labor or excessive sexual activity, leading to depletion of vital energy. A popular saying is: "One stone of rice sore," implying it can be cured after a hundred days.[195p]
If one can greatly tonify the qi and blood, recovery can occur in a few days—why then require a hundred days? The healing of wounds depends on the abundance of qi and blood. I once treated a scholar named Ling Daizhi who suffered from deficiency and took harmful medications, nearly resulting in a critical state. I prescribed a remedy to strengthen his spleen, and he recovered. Scholar Wang Wenyuan suffered from labor and ailments, took Xiao Chaihu Decoction, which resolved exterior symptoms, and later used my remedy to drain and treated the abscess, recovering in several days. Judge Hu had clear pus and weak veins; he only used tonifying medicine and was healed. However, after recently marrying, he relapsed and self-administered a detoxifying decoction, leading to uncontrolled diarrhea and ultimately death. This illustrates that such conditions are often due to insufficiency and must be tonified. Generally, pustules belong to the liver meridian; initially, they are firm and hard due to the liver's dominance over the tendons. After five to seven days, they should become red and soft with pus; if still hard, it indicates deficiency of the original qi, unable to decompose. Often, people see hardness and only want to remove it internally, inadvertently taking aggressive herbs that lead to further deficiency. The previously mentioned cases are examples of this issue.

Additionally, here is a prescription for treating pustules.[196p]
Shanzhi, Dahuang, Ru Xiang, Mo Yao, and Dang Gui each half qian; (Cao She) Lou Ren two qian; Dai Zhi Shi one qian. Prepare one dose, decoct in water.

Chuan Lian Zi Wan is used to treat hernias and all ailments in the lower body, all of which can be cured. Even if swelling and pain have persisted for many years, taking this medicine will eliminate the root cause forever.

For preparation, take one pound of cleaned Chuan Lian Zi, divided into four portions: use four ounces with one drachm of wheat bran and fry with forty-nine grasshoppers until the bran turns yellow, then discard the bran and grasshoppers; use four ounces with one drachm of castor beans and fry the same way; use four ounces with one drachm of Ba Jiao and also fry; use four ounces with one ounce of salt and one drachm of Chuan Huixiang in the same manner, then discard the salt and Huixiang.

Do not apply heat to Mu Xiang; instead, fry old paper until fragrant, using one ounce of each.

Grind all of the above into a fine powder, mix with wine to form pills the size of a wutong seed. Take fifty pills at a time, swallowed with salty broth, and for severe cases, up to three doses a day on an empty stomach before meals.

Treats (hereditary) hernia.

Treats small intestine hernia, bladder prolapse. For those who have not responded to medicine after a long time, this remedy is effective.

Wutou Guizhi Decoction (from "Jinkui Yaolue," same below)
For treating cold hernias.
Guizhi (cinnamon twig) peeled, Shaoyao (peony root), fresh ginger, each 3 liang; honey-fried licorice, 2 liang; 12 jujubes, smashed.

After obtaining 1 sheng, initially take 2 he; if unknown, take 3 he; again unknown, increase to 5 he. In those who are aware, if they appear drunk and vomit, it signifies a middle disease.

Wutou Decoction
Five large Wutou pieces, skin removed, unchewed.
Use 3 sheng of water, boil to extract 1 sheng, strain, add 2 sheng of honey, boil until the moisture is gone, retain 2 sheng. Strong individuals can take 7 he, weak individuals 5 he. If not healed, take it again the next day. If unable to take, repeat twice daily.

Hulu Ba Pills (from "Heji")
For treating small intestine hernias, with descent of Yin swelling, a mass in the lower abdomen resembling an egg, moving up and down, causing intolerable pain, or tied up around the navel, leading to vomiting and unrest.
One jin of roasted Hulu Ba (cucumber seeds), 12 liang of roasted fennel salt, 10 liang of washed and roasted Wuzhuyu (evodia fruit), 1 jin 2 liang of roasted Chuanlianzizi (melia fruit) with pits removed, 6 liang each of heart-removed Ba Jizhi (morinda root) and prepared Chuanwu (prepared aconite).
Grind these into powder, mix with wine to form pills the size of tung seeds, take 15 to 20 pills each time, downed with warm wine on an empty stomach. For children, take 5 pills downed with fennel soup. One formula includes black Qian Niu.[203p]

Cangcu San (also known as Zhifu Decoction) is used to treat sudden abdominal pain due to cold hernia and for conditions affecting the small intestine and bladder with stabbing pain. When the spleen and kidney's qi attacks suddenly, resulting in unbearable pain, inability to bend or stretch, and a cold, heavy sensation in the abdomen akin to a stone, with white fluid excretion.

Ingredients: 49 pieces of mountain gardenia, burned until half done; 1 piece of aconite, processed;
Take 2 qian (a traditional weight unit) of the right powder, mix with 1 cup of water and half a cup of wine, decoct until reduced to 7 parts, add a pinch of salt, and take it warm for immediate relief.

Muxiang Daqi Wan treats men’s abdominal pain due to small intestine qi and all kinds of qi accumulation, replenishing the lower source's cold deficiency.

Ingredients: 1 liang (another traditional weight unit) each of wood incense, frankincense, and kernel-free flos fraxini; star anise, fennel, clove, cyperus, broken old paper, and hu lu ba; 3 leng (another herb), 1 liang of licorice; half a liang of duzhong, fried and stripped of silk.

Bushan Tang is used for cold hernia entering the abdomen, small intestine pain, and recurrent diarrhea, as well as chest distention.

Ingredients: 5 fen (a smaller weight) of agarwood; 1.5 qian each of ginseng, poria, processed aconite (skin and navel removed), astragalus, white atractylodes, and papaya; 1 qian each of qianghuo, angelica, perilla, and roasted licorice.
These should be prepared as one dose with 2 zhong of water, 3 slices of ginger, and 1 red date, decocted for 1 zhong and consumed before meals. For vomiting, add 1 qian of pinellia and 7 slices of fresh ginger to decoct and consume.[205p]

Yaozi San, for treating painful kidney qi.
Fried black morning glory and fried white morning glory, equal parts.
Grind them into a fine powder. For each use, take three qian, and for one pair of pig kidneys, cut them thin and stitch them together. Add fifty grains of Sichuan pepper and one hundred grains of fennel, mixing the morning glory powder evenly into the kidneys. Tie them with thread, wrap them in damp paper several times, and stew until fragrant and cooked. Take them out to release steam, chew hollowly while drinking good wine. After a while, rest, and by dawn, remove the foul substance, and you will be cured.[207p]
Prescription for Kidney Pain
For the treatment of men's kidney qi and women's blood qi, when the pain becomes unbearable, with a blue face and black lips, nearly to the point of no return. For men, this attacks the organs, causing pain in the lower back; for women, it forms lumps in the abdomen, leading to sudden pain that can be dangerously debilitating, with pain persisting year after year. Those experiencing this pain should take this remedy.

Ingredients:

  • Dong Quai (Angelica sinensis) 1 qian
  • White Peony 1 qian
  • Myrrh
  • Qilin Grass
  • Corydalis
  • Poria
  • Three-Lobed Bletilla
  • Cowherb, boiled and roasted dry 1/2 liang
  • Wood Fragrance 1/2 liang
  • Wolf Poison 1/2 liang, crushed
  • Cynanchum 4 liang, combined with Wolf Poison, stir-fried until yellow

Preparation: First, process the Cynanchum and Wolf Poison, grinding them into a paste in a mortar. Then, combine Qilin Grass and others, grinding them into a fine powder. Lastly, mix the powders of Cynanchum, Wolf Poison, Qilin Grass, Myrrh, and others, grinding thousands of times. Each serving is 1.5 qian, taken with green onion wine during episodes of qi pain. Do not consume after a full meal. If there is severe heat in the intestines, and one is unable to pass stool, with blackened lips and excessive salivation, taking this remedy once is effective.

Litchi powder treats hernia with enlarged testicles, causing unbearable pain. Take fourteen fresh litchi seeds, burn them to ash and preserve the essence. Three-layer fennel pills treat deficiency in the kidneys and bladder. When pathogenic qi binds together, it leads to cold hernia, lingering and not dispersing, causing pain in the navel and abdomen, with the testicles enlarged, skin swelling and heavier, hindering movement, causing persistent itching, sometimes leading to yellow fluid discharge that forms sores, or strange growths, repeatedly unhealed, resulting in blockage of the kidney meridian, with yin and yang not flowing. The outer kidney becomes swollen and hard like stone, growing larger, due to frequent intake of hot medicinal herbs or improper handling. The remedy warms and guides yang qi, gradually dispelling cold evils, tonifying deficiencies, reducing hernias, and nourishing the kidney meridian, enabling restoration. For small intestine cold hernia afflictions, a short course with just three doses can lead to complete recovery.[213p]
First Prescription
Take half a tael of salt to fry the imported fennel until it turns yellow and then mix it with a weighed amount of sand ginseng and one tael each of prepared bitter orange and wood fragrance. Grind them into a fine powder, then combine with rice paste to form pills the size of a tung seed. Take twenty pills each time, on an empty stomach, with warm wine or salty broth, three times a day. For minor ailments, this dose should suffice. If symptoms persist, proceed to the second prescription.

Second Prescription
Add one tael of prickly ash and half a tael of betel nut to the previous herbs. Combine all six ingredients into a powder, weighing five and a half taels, and form into pills as before. If the illness is not cured, take the third prescription.

Third Prescription
Add four taels of poria and half a tael or one tael of black aconite, prepared without the peel and navel, to the previous ingredients. All eight ingredients combined should weigh ten taels, then make into pills as previously described, increasing the number to thirty pills. This is effective for frequent small intestine gas or chronic cold hernias as large as a gourd, effectively resolving the issue.

Spider Powder
Cures fox hernia.
Ingredients: 14 pieces of spider, fried until charred; 0.5 qian of cinnamon, from a thicker cut.
Grind the above into powder. Take 1 qian each time; honey pill is also acceptable. Lei Gong says: For all uses of spiders, do not use those with five colors, or those with spiny hairs, or with a thin and small body. Look for those with webs in the southwest of the house, small body and large abdomen, with a yellow pus inside, as they are genuine. For use, remove the head and legs, grind into a paste, and mix with the medicine. If charred, it will have no effect.

Xiangfu San treats swollen hernias and small intestine gas. The amount of Xiangfu is not restricted. First, prepare it as a powder. Each time, use a cup of wine and one qian of kelp, boiled down to half a cup. First, take the kelp and chew it finely, then mix it with two qian of Xiangfu powder using the boiled wine. Another method uses kelp ground into powder mixed with hot wine, which is especially effective. In severe cases, it can be taken as an infusion. Another method uses hot wine to take Jingjie powder.

Hai Zao Wan treats small intestine gas effectively.

For the potion, take twenty-eight pieces each of Dung Beetle and Croton, removing the shells entirely; one liang each of kelp and kombu. Take the Dung Beetle and Croton, put them in a silk bag, use a bowl of good vinegar to boil the four ingredients in a clay pot until dry, then discard the Dung Beetle and Croton. Grind the two types of seaweed into powder, boil with one hundred grains of plain fermented soybeans, lightly soak in the remaining vinegar, then steam into a paste. Mix this with the powdered medicine to form pills the size of a walnut. Each time, take a small amount of musk and three qian of cinnabar, grind finely in a mortar until silent, then mix in the musk to coat the pills, and let them dry in the sun. Store them in a new clay bottle.

Initially, take seven pills, then ten pills, and on the third dose, take fifteen pills. If not cured, take three more doses, using a total of fifteen pills, and continue with salt-fried fennel seeds chewed and swallowed with wine on an empty stomach. Avoid duck and spicy fermented sauces that can cause gas. For chronic illnesses, three to five doses will be effective. This medicine is valuable, fresh, and acts quickly. If taken longer, it is better to increase the dosage.[219p]

Front Yin Gate

Formula

(Nodular Hernia) Hernia Formula [from "Thousand Gold Prescriptions"]

  • 50 pieces each of peach kernel and spider
  • 2 taels each of cinnamon heart, tribulus seed, water plantain, earth nut, fangfeng (siler root), five-flavored fruit, tangerine peel, and poria
  • 1 tael each of peony bark, asarum (wild ginger), and seaweed
  • One complete fox genitals

Grind these sixteen ingredients into a fine powder, mix with honey, and form into pills the size of a wutou (a type of nut). Initially take 10 pills, gradually increasing to 30 pills. For the nodular area, apply one pill to the two corners of the claws and half a pill to the tips of the claws. Perform moxibustion on the points seven times. Cure.

[In the segment regarding moxibustion, from "Thousand Gold," it is recorded that for the condition of sudden swelling in the lower regions, align both feet together with the big toes touching, allowing the claws to meet. The Complete Deer Pill nourishes Yang, replenishes deficiencies, and its benefits cannot be fully described. If a person takes one dose, it can extend life by a decade. The preparation must be shared by four people who each consume a portion of one deer. After a year, they prepare it again together, and after four years, each person will have one complete deer. If one person prepares a dose alone, it risks spoiling over time and losing its medicinal potency.

To make it, take a deer, kill it, remove the hair, wash out the internal organs, and cook the deer meat with wine until done. Cut the meat into strips and dry it to a powder. Take the skin, mix it, and boil it with the original broth to form a paste. Combine this paste with the meat powder and honey to form pills. Its bones should be roasted and powdered, then mixed with ginseng, white atractylodes, poria, honey-fried licorice, angelica, ligusticum, raw and cooked rehmannia, honey-fried astragalus, asparagus, wheat, goji berries, eucommia treated with salty water, prepared ox knee with wine, yam, water chestnut, dodder seed, morinda, schisandra, cistanche mixed with wine, prepared lotus root with wine, and raspberry treated with wine, along with autumn stones, ligusticum, and dried tangerine peel, each one tael.

First, the medicinal ingredients must be finely powdered and mixed thoroughly. Once the deer glue is ready, combine it with the mixture to form pills the size of apricot seeds, then dry them. Use raw yellow silk to make fifty small bags, each capable of holding about one pound, and hang them in a well-ventilated place. After consuming one bag, take another. On damp days, it is advisable to warm them over a fire a couple of times. Each dose is eight to ninety pills, taken on an empty stomach before bedtime, washed down with ginger soup, salt soup, clear soup, or warm wine in winter is also acceptable.[234p]

Bai Cao Jian (Hundred Herbs Decoction) treats various types of carbuncles and toxins, wounds, painful rotten flesh, swelling, and conditions caused by wind, cold, and dampness. It has remarkable effects on all such ailments.

The herbs gathered from fields and mountains can be used indiscriminately, although mountain herbs are preferred, particularly those that are aromatic and pungent. In winter, dried herbs may be used, but they must be harvested in advance.

Regardless of quantity, prepare a concentrated decoction by boiling it down, and while hot, use it to steam and wash the affected area, applying it with a cloth. After a considerable time, ensure that the medicinal vapor thoroughly penetrates, and then apply other medicines. This should be done two to three times daily as often as possible.

The cooling properties of certain herbs can dispel heat, while warming ones can disperse cold. Aromatic herbs can promote the flow of qi, and detoxifying ones can eliminate toxins. Every herb has its use and benefit. When the decoction captures the properties of the herbs, its vapor becomes harmless; when the herbs absorb the vapor, their power is enhanced.

The principle of using various herbs to create a decoction follows this reasoning. This method is indeed one of the most essential and effective in surgery, also shared with those outside the medical profession.[251p]
Piao Xiao San is used to treat damp-heat necrosis, toxic sores with oozing, or sores in the lower part of the kidney capsule, and for swollen and painful sores in the groin, all of which yield miraculous effects. Hai Piao Xiao is divided into equal parts with "Ren Zhong Bai" (or "Ren Zhong Huang" or "Nai Sha" is also acceptable).

Make a fine powder of the above, first boil a strong decoction of various herbs, then use it hot to steam and wash the affected area, followed by applying this medication. If it is dry, mix with sesame oil, rendered pig fat, or honey water for application. If swollen and very painful, adding a bit of borneol is even better. For wet sores with much pus, adding equal parts of Mi Tuo Sang (or calcined alum powder) is also recommended; mixing with calcined Lu Gan Shi (heavy metal) is even more effective.

Yin Zhu Yan is for treating lice in the hair and other insect-infested sores. Use a finger to rub the smoke onto the scalp and cover it with a wool hat, then all lice will be eradicated. This smoke can also be made into cakes with jujube pulp, or formed into pills, or rubbed on between cooked pig or chicken livers for application to insect-infested sores and ringworm. For insects affecting the anal area, a jujube pill wrapped in cotton can be inserted into the anus overnight, and it will certainly be effective. Be sure to leave some cotton hanging outside for easy removal.[252p]

  7. For inguinal hernia and retractile testicular cysts: use pumice stone powdered, take two qian with a decoction of mutong, red poria, and mai men dong.

Guo Lao Tang: For treating hanging sores.     Acupuncture

The "Su Wen" states: When there is low back pain, one cannot turn or shake; urgently needling the Yin and egg points, the eight hui points should be needled alongside the pain. The eight hui points are located between the waist and buttocks. When there is disease in the lower abdomen with abdominal pain, preventing bowel movements, the condition is called hernia, caused by cold. Needle between the lower abdomen and thighs, and between the ankle bone and the waist. Needling should be thorough to promote healing; with needling, the illness is resolved.

The Du meridian begins from the center of the bones below the lower abdomen. In women, it connects to the uterus cavity, which is situated at the end of the urinary opening; it transmits to the yin organs, encircles the coccyx, separates and connects to the perineium, and merges with the major yang energy in the body, linking to the lesser yin on the inner side of the thigh and penetrating the spine to associate with the kidneys. For men, it follows the penis down to the perineum, similar to women. When illness arises and rushes from the lower abdomen up to the heart causing pain, preventing forward and backward movement, it is called "chong hernia." Women may experience infertility, urinary retention, incontinence, and dry throat. Illness in the Du meridian is treated along the Du meridian itself, preferably at the bones, and in severe cases, below the navel.

Evil influences affecting the foot's jueyin meridian can cause sudden severe pain from hernia. Needle the area where the big toe's nail and flesh meet, for both men and women. Treat the left for the right, and the right for the left.

The "Ling Shu" says: The pain in the muscles of the foot's taiyin meridian is associated with the pain of the yin organs, pulling down to the sides of the abdomen, treated with fire needles and points, using the pain as a guide for method.

The small intestine controls the testicles, pulling the spine upward to the heart, where evil resides in the small intestine, connecting to the testicular cords, relating to the spine, penetrating the liver and lung, and linking to the heart cord.[289p]
When the qi is abundant, it causes counterflow and upward surging, affecting the liver through the intestines and stomach. It disperses to the diaphragm and is tied at the navel, thus one should take from the diaphragm to disperse. Use the taiyin point to give relief, taking from below the jueyin, and also from the juxu and xialian points to eliminate it. Press along the pathways it travels to regulate it.

The foot jueyin diverges, termed ligou, located five inches from the inner ankle, it separately travels to the shaoyang. Its pathway ascends through the shins and concludes at the testes. When the qi is reversed, it causes swelling and sudden hernias; if excess, it protrudes, and if deficient, it is violently itching, hence the treatment is at its divergence.

For issues in the small intestine, there is pain in the lower abdomen, with aching in the waist and spine radiating to the testes. At times this aggravates and brings heat to the front of the ear. If there is intense cold, the heat might be only on one shoulder, and if severe, heat can be felt between the little finger and next finger. If the pulse is sunken, this is the sign.

Hand taiyang issues should be treated by using the juxu and xialian points. The "Yao Yi Jing" states: For pain in the waist and legs that is clear, it is good to press the testes and jump, with the shangjiao as the main point.

For sudden acute pain in the lower back, heavy pain in the lower regions, and inability to urinate, zhi bian is the treatment.

When there is pain in the lower abdomen affecting the testes, pulling on the waist and spine, with hernia pain surging to the heart, if the waist and spine are stiff, with yellow or red urine, and dry mouth, the small intestine shu point is the treatment.

For fox hernia with palpitations and shortness of breath, treat at the juxu point.

For pain in the lower abdomen and difficulty urinating, along the lateral bones is where treatment should focus.

For pain in the lower abdomen related to hernia, if lying down induces anxiety, the qihai point should be treated.[290p]
For violent hernias, which cause great heat in the lower abdomen, it is governed by the Guanyuan point.
For yin hernias and qi hernias, the Tianshu point is the main point.
For (a certain type of) hernia, the Dajue and Digong points are the main points.
For yin hernias with pain in the inner genitals, and with both testicles rising, where one cannot lie on their back, the Xiejie point is the main point.
For yin hernias, the Chongmen point is the main point.
For male hernias with testicles moving up and down, accompanied by pain in the lower abdomen, the Wushu point is the main point.
For internal pain in the inner thigh, qi accumulation, where the fox hernia moves up and down, pulling on the lower abdomen, causing unbearable pain with bending or lying flat, the Shangqiu point is the main point.
For the fox hernia, the Taichong point is the main point.[291p]
The text describes a series of medical symptoms and their associated treatments, which can be summarized as follows:

  • When there is difficulty and pain in urination, accompanied by a sensation of cold in the lower abdomen, or if there is swelling and pain in the umbilical area with feelings of unhappiness, treat with Dazhun.
  • For severe abdominal pain radiating to the heart, and fullness below the heart leading to pain in the genitals, accompanied by anger and inability to see clearly, treat with Xingjian.
  • For acute pain in the lower regions, treat with Zhongfeng.
  • When experiencing pain in the navel and lower abdomen along with lumbar pain, manage with Zhongfeng.
  • If there is urgency in urination and pain in the inner thigh area, treat with Jiaoxin.
  • Pain in the genitals and lumbar region, with symptoms of hardening, cold and heat sensation, and swelling in the testicles leading to obstructed urination, anxiety, fullness in the abdomen, and pain in the lower abdomen, can be managed with Ligou.
  • In men, when there is jumping pain in the genitals, feelings of fullness in the abdomen, pressure in the sides, and inability to urinate, it may lead to various pains throughout the body, sweating difficulties, and a sense of losing control, treat with Yungquan.
  • For obstructed urination and related symptoms, manage with Rangu.

This interpretation organizes the symptoms and the recommended treatments based on the ancient medical understanding presented in the text.[292p]
When suffering from hernia, with pain in the lower abdomen, the point "Zhaohai" is to be treated. For pain on the left, treat the right; for pain on the right, treat the left; the treatment is immediate. For hernia, when the limbs feel heavy and the body is oppressed, "Zhiyin" is the main point to address.

The "Qianjin Fang" states: loss of essence leads to muscle spasms and the penis drawing into the abdomen, causing referred pain. Cauterize 50 times at the middle of the tendon in front of the inner ankle. It further mentions: cauterize 50 times below the malleolus for adults; for children, follow the age-adjusted method. The point at the perineum is for coldness in the head of the penis.

The point "Xingjian" is for pain in the shaft, and "Yingu" is for impotence and urgent pulling pain in the lower abdomen. For hernia (ta), cauterize 10 times beneath the big toe, and along the edges where swelling occurs. The "Zhou Hou Fang" states: cauterize 5 times at the center below the second joint of the foot’s second toe. According to the Yao family, the third joint of the toe should have 3 cauterizations.

For painful swelling at the genitals, cauterize 3 times at "Datun." "Ququan" manages the hernia with pain that radiates to the belly button, presenting with an inability to urinate and impotence. Another source indicates pain radiating from the penis with inability to urinate. "Zhongdu" addresses pecuniary hernia and severe cases with no awareness of surroundings.

"Zhongwan" deals with "chong" hernia, which can be fatal with no awareness of the person.[293p]
In He yang and Zhong qi, the primary focus is on the pain caused by hernia and internal bleeding, accompanied by abdominal pain, intestinal disorders, and severe pelvic pain.

Zhao hai regulates the limbs' disorders and the heat of the body, leading to hernia.

Tai xi addresses large hernias and accumulations within the uterus, affecting the pelvic region.

Guan yuan deals with hernia issues and also refers to acute hernia pain.

Jian jing, located at the shoulder girdle where it connects with the arm, governs lateral hernias.

The points around the umbilicus, including Shi men, Tian shuo, and Qi hai, target lower abdominal hernias, influence the internal organs, and can lead to pain around the navel and chest, with difficulty in breathing.

Si man specifically addresses accumulations beneath the navel.

Da yin xie and Chong men focus on hernia-related issues, particularly in the pelvic area.

Tian shuo governs gas hernias and vomiting.

Da ju deals with hernias that are particularly neglected.

Shao fu addresses pelvic pain that varies in intensity, with cold and heat symptoms, sudden onset of pain, frequent urination, and can lead to itching, gastrointestinal reversals, acute hernia, and difficulty in urination.

Da he and ran gu focus on seminal overflow and retraction of the pelvic organs.

Yin shi predominates in cold hernias that cause pain in the lower abdomen, hips, knees, and waist akin to clear water, with various lower abdominal complaints corrected from "pain" in the text. Pressing down may lead to knee pain, with symptoms of cold hernias leading to abdominal distension and weakness.

Tai chong, Zhong feng, and Di ji address hernias with insufficient essence, with Tai chong also associated with fox hernias and symptoms of nausea and fainting.

Yin jiao and Shi men focus on issues concerning the testes. Shi men also addresses abdominal distension due to hernias.

Tai chong handles retraction of the testes and cases where the abdomen is firm and uncomfortable for lying down.[294p]
The "Jisheng Fang" states: For the illness of large slippage, the key point is located three inches below the umbilicus. Moxibustion with one hundred cups is effective. For the seven types of hernia, take half a pound of salt, fry it until extremely hot, and use a cloth bag to apply it to the painful area. The "Records of the Grand Historian" states: Duke Cheng of Anling in Banli was stricken with an illness. I examined the pulse and concluded it was a type of hernia. This hernia is located beneath the diaphragm and connects to the lungs, resulting from an internal condition. My advice is to avoid strenuous activities. Engaging in such activities would surely lead to vomiting blood and death. Upon further examination, I indicated that the patient was unlikely to survive until morning; they were destined to die. This condition arises internally. Hence, I recognized that the patient would show signs of a pulse related to Fan Yang, which indicates a void within them. The prognosis is fatal. The cycle of life and death is intertwined with this hernia. I also noted that other diagnoses could determine survival and that numerous illnesses have been treated over time, making it difficult for me to recall or provide a complete diagnosis. I do not dare to respond with certainty.[302p]
The wife of the Minister of State from Qi's Northern Palace fell ill. All the doctors believed it to be an invasion of wind causing an illness in the middle, affecting the lungs, and they treated her by needling the Lesser Yang meridian in her feet. I, however, diagnosed her pulse and concluded: the pathological condition was a dampness obstructing the bladder, causing difficulty both in urination and defecation, with urine appearing red. When exposed to cold, it led to involuntary urination, resulting in abdominal swelling. Due to the illness, when she felt the need to urinate, she could not. This blockage was due to the disease. Hence, I discerned that those who were ill had strong and solid pulses, but their arrival was difficult, indicating the movement of the Jueyin. A difficult pulse indicates dampness obstructing the bladder. The abdominal swelling signals a blockage in the small abdomen caused by the Jueyin. When the Jueyin is excessive, the pulse becomes knotty; when it moves, it causes abdominal swelling. I suggest moxibusting the Jueyin meridians in her feet, one on each side, which will prevent involuntary urination and promote clear urination, alleviating her abdominal pain. Additionally, I shall prepare a medicinal decoction for her. After three days, the dampness will dissipate, and she will recover.[303p]
The "Records of Travels and Official Matters" states: When Xin Jiaxuan first returned from the north to serve in Jiangnan, he suddenly suffered from a severe illness related to the testicles, which swelled large like a cup. Each time, he would mix this paste with two qian of non-ash liquor and consume it, thus achieving a cure. In his later years, Mr. Sha Sui also contracted this illness, and Xin taught him this remedy, which also cured him. However, people in the city cannot find leaf pearls, so they can simply buy Coix seeds from herbal shops, which are also effective. For those who wish to lighten their bodies and prolong life, it has a sweet, slightly cold, and non-toxic flavor. It is primarily used to alleviate contractions that hinder movement, remove wind and dampness, ease breathlessness, eliminate cold and evil qi from the muscles and bones, benefit the digestive system, reduce edema, and improve appetite; prolonged use can lighten the body and enhance energy. His appetite gradually improved, and his bowel movements became more solid. I later removed the two extra herbs, and after over a month he recovered. He continued to take the "Liuwei Dihuang Pill" for more than three months, and his condition returned to normal. Furthermore, the "Qiongyu Paste," "Guben Pill," and "Kanli Pill" are all remedies for cold and fire reduction; if the intestines and stomach are not dry and hot, they are not suitable. If taken for an extended period by someone with yin deficiency causing heat, it could lead to infertility, as it depletes yang qi and thus yin blood cannot be generated. The text "Yuyi Cao" states: "To nurture the essence of Master Wang Taigong, one's spirit should be kept inward, and in all matters, one should practice humility and retreat. Therefore, when the illness attacks the stomach, there will be severe vomiting; when it attacks the top of the head, there will be trembling and fear of cold, and the stability of breathing will be disturbed. Last winter, I observed a sudden onset of symptoms, realizing it was due to the upward invasion of earth qi. I urgently used a strong dose of ginseng, aconite, ginger, and cinnamon to treat it, and it was cured after just one dose. Since then, whenever such symptoms arise, I've relied on ginger and cinnamon for quick effects. However, I doubted the condition's severity, not the medicine's efficacy.
