　　　　　阴肿湿

　　心水者，其身重而少气，不得卧，烦而躁，其人阴肿。　　肾水者，其腹大，脐肿腰痛，不得溺，阴下湿如牛鼻上汗，其足逆冷，面反瘦。[20p]

On the Spirit

When the liver is sorrowful, it affects the spirit within, and when the spirit is harmed, one becomes crazed and forgetful, lacking focus. Without focus, one cannot be correct; the body becomes contracted and the muscles spasm, the ribs cannot rise, the hair fades, and the complexion withers, leading to death in autumn.

On the Organs

The depression behind the ears relates to the kidneys; when the kidneys are affected, it results in the condition known as "fox hernia."

Essentials of the Gold Repository (Han Zhang Ji)

On Dampness and Swelling

When the heart is troubled, the body feels heavy and lacks energy, making it hard to lie down, resulting in restlessness and agitation; this person experiences swelling. When kidney water accumulates, the abdomen becomes large, the navel swells, there is pain in the waist, inability to urinate, and dampness in the lower regions like sweat on a cow’s nose; the feet feel abnormally cold, while the face appears lean.[20p]

　　　　　阴吹

　　胃气下泄，阴吹而正喧，此谷气之实也。膏发煎导之。
　　　　　食忌

　　鱼无肠胆者不可食。食之，三年阴不起，女子绝生。
　　　　　疝

　　腹痛，脉弦而紧，弦则卫气不行，即恶寒，紧则不欲食，邪正相搏，即为寒疝。寒疝绕脐痛。若发则白津出，手足厥冷。其脉沉紧者，大乌头煎主之。　　寒疝腹中痛，及胁痛里急者，当归生姜羊肉汤主之。寒疝，腹中痛，逆冷，手足不仁。若身疼痛，灸刺诸药不能治，抵当乌头桂枝汤主之。　　其脉数而紧乃弦，状如弓弦，按之不移。脉数弦者，当下其寒。脉紧大而迟者，必心下坚。脉大而紧者，阳中有阴，可下之。　　趺阳脉当伏，今反紧，本自有寒疝瘕，腹中痛，医反下之，下之即胸满短气。　　阴狐疝气者，偏有小大，时时上下，蜘蛛散主之。
　　　　　阴蚀

　　少阴脉滑而数者，阴中即生疮，阴中蚀，疮烂者，狼牙汤洗之。
　　　　中藏经 【汉　华佗】[21p]

Yin Blowing

Stomach qi descends, with yin blowing and a proper noise; this is the essence of the valley qi. Fat must be boiled and guided.

Dietary Restrictions

Fish without intestines and gallbladder should not be eaten. Consuming it can lead to three years of unresolved yin, causing women to become infertile.

Hernia

Abdominal pain, with a pulse that is taut and tight; the tautness indicates that defensive qi is obstructed, and one feels aversion to cold. The tightness indicates a lack of appetite, a struggle between evil and proper, leading to cold hernia. Cold hernia causes pain around the navel. If it develops, white fluid may ooze out, and the hands and feet will feel cold. If the pulse is deep and tight, major aconite decoction is indicated. Cold hernia leading to abdominal pain and side pain with urgency is treated with angelica, ginger, and lamb soup. For cold hernia with abdominal pain, counterflow of cold, and numbness in hands and feet, if there is body pain and moxibustion or acupuncture cannot treat it, the aconite and cinnamon twig decoction should be used.

If the pulse is rapid and tight, resembling a bowstring, and does not change when pressed, it indicates the need to expel cold. A rapid and taut pulse suggests the cold needs to be expelled. A large and tight pulse indicates a firm heart area. A large and tight pulse also suggests the presence of yin amidst yang, which can be expelled. The foot yang pulse should be depressed, but if it is instead taut, it must indicate existing cold hernia and abdominal pain; if treated by expelling downward, it will cause fullness in the chest and shortness of breath.

In cases of yin fox hernia gas, it may vary in size, rising and falling from time to time; spiderwort powder is indicated.

Yin Erosion

If the lesser yin pulse is slippery and rapid, sores will arise within yin; when yin is eroded and sores decay, they should be washed with wolf teeth decoction.

From the "Middle Vault Classic" by Han Huo Tuo[21p]

　　　　　阴(疒颓)

　　(疒颓)有四种：有肠(疒颓)、卵胀、气(疒颓)、水(疒颓)。肠(疒颓)、卵胀，难瘥。气(疒颓)、水(疒颓)，针灸易治。
　　　　　妬精疮

　　有人自少至长，阴下常有干癣者，宜依癣方主之。有五劳七伤而得阴下痒湿，搔之黄汁出者，宜用补丸散主之，仍须敷药治之。亦有患妒精疮者，以妒精方治之。夫妒精疮者，男子在阴头节下，妇人在玉门内，并似疳疮。作臼齐食之大痛，疳即不痛也。　　跌阳脉滑而数，法当下重。少阴脉滑而数，妇人阴中生疮。[22p]

Egg Shrinkage

When cold in the spleen and heat is sufficient, it causes abdominal pain without appetite; it also affects the tongue, leading to strong speech and egg shrinkage, pulling the pain into the groin.

Diagnosis of Life and Death

Anyone with a rolled tongue and egg shrinkage is doomed to die. If the palms are swollen without lines, the navel is swollen outward, and both the scrotum and penis are swollen, death is imminent.

Hernia Pulse

If the pulse in the left wrist is absent, then the small intestine is lacking. Death occurs in six days. The disease indicates a hernia in the navel, spleen, and lower abdomen.

Thousand Gold Prescriptions (Tang Dynasty, Sun Simiao)

Yin (Falling Sickness)

(Falling sickness) has four types: intestinal (falling sickness), egg swelling, gas (falling sickness), and water (falling sickness). Intestinal (falling sickness) and egg swelling are hard to cure. Gas (falling sickness) and water (falling sickness) are easier to treat with acupuncture.

Jealousy Sores

If a person experiences dry eczema under the genitals from youth to adulthood, they should follow the eczema prescription for it. If suffering from five strains and seven injuries leading to itching and moistness under the genitals, with yellow fluid upon scratching, they should use a nourishing pill powder and additionally apply medication for treatment. There are also those afflicted with jealousy sores, to be treated with the jealousy sore prescription. Jealousy sores occur for men at the head of the penis and for women inside the vaginal door, resembling canker sores. Eating certain foods leads to great pain, but canker sores do not cause pain. The pulse in the falling yang is slippery and rapid, thus should be treated with heavier measures. The minor yin pulse is slippery and rapid, indicating sores forming in the woman’s genitals.[22p]

　　　　活人书 【宋　朱肱】

　　　　　囊缩

　　伤寒六七日，烦满囊缩，其脉尺寸俱微缓，此足厥阴肝经受病也。　　脉浮缓，必囊不缩，外证必发热恶寒似疟，为欲愈，宜桂枝麻黄各半汤。若尺寸脉俱沉短者，必是囊缩，毒气入脏，宜承气汤下之。　　大抵伤寒病，脏腑传变，阳经先受病，故次第传入阴经。以阳主生，故太阳水传足阳明土，土传足少阳木，为微邪也。阴主杀，故木传足太阴土，土传足少阴水，水传足厥阴木。至六七日，当传厥阴肝木，必移气克于脾土，脾再受贼邪，则五脏六腑皆困而危殆。营卫不通，耳聋囊缩，不知人而死矣。速用承气汤下之，可保五死一生。古人云：脾热病则五脏危。又云：土败木贼则死。若第六七日传厥阴，脉得微缓、微浮为脾胃脉，故知脾气全，不再受客，邪无所容，否极泰来，营卫将复，水升火降，则寒热作而大汗解矣。[23p]

The Book of Living (Huo Ren Shu) by Zhu Hong (Song Dynasty)

Contraction of the Sac

After seven days of severe cold damage, if the abdomen is full and contracted, the pulse is both thin and weak; this indicates that the foot Jueyin Liver Meridian is affected. If the pulse is floating and weak, the abdomen will not contract, and there will be external signs of fever and chills, similar to malaria. To recover, one should use a decoction of equal parts Guizhi and Mahuang. If the pulses are both deep and short, this indicates contraction of the abdomen, with toxic qi entering the organs; one should use Chengqi Decoction to purge it.

Generally, in cases of severe cold damage, the transmission of disease occurs first in the yang organs, and then sequentially moves into the yin organs. Since yang governs life, the Taiyang water transmits to the Foot Yangming earth, which then transmits to the Foot Shaoyang wood as a slight pathogenic factor. Yin governs death, so wood transmits to the Foot Taiyin earth, which then transmits to the Foot Shaoyin water, and water transmits to the Foot Jueyin wood. By the sixth or seventh day, if it has transmitted to the Jueyin Liver wood, it must transfer qi to invade the Spleen earth. If the Spleen is repeatedly subjected to the invading evil, then all five organs and six viscera will be burdened and perilous.

When the Ying and wei (nutritive and defensive) energies are obstructed, the ears may become deaf and the abdomen may contract, resulting in being unaware and leading to death. Prompt use of Chengqi Decoction can secure the possibility of saving one out of five lives. The ancients said: "In cases of Spleen heat disease, the five organs become precarious." They also said: "When earth fails and wood invades, it results in death." If by the sixth or seventh day it transmits to Jueyin and the pulse is slightly weak and slightly floating, this indicates the Spleen and Stomach pulse is intact, knowing that the Spleen qi is complete and no longer accepts the guest, the evil has no place to reside; the extreme will turn into the favorable, the Ying and wei will recover, water will rise and fire will descend, leading to the occurrence of cold and heat, and a great sweat will resolve the condition.[23p]

　　　　济生方 【宋　严用和】

　　　　　七疝

　　巢氏云：疝者痛也，皆由荣卫虚弱，饮食寒温不调，致风冷邪气，乘虚入于腹中，遂成诸疝。发则小腹疼痛，痛或绕脐，或逆上抢心，引心背痛。甚则手足厥冷，自汗呕逆，或大小便秘难。大抵诸疝之脉当弦紧。盖弦者寒也，紧者痛也。疝有七证，厥疝、症疝、寒疝、气疝、盘疝、附疝、狼疝是也。何以言之？厥疝则心痛足冷，食已则吐；症疝腹中气乍满，气积如臂；寒疝因寒饮食，卒然胁下腹中痛；气疝腹中乍满乍减而痛；盘疝腹中痛引脐旁；附疝腹痛连脐下有积聚；狼疝小腹与阴相引而痛。诸疝不愈，邪气留滞，乃成积聚。其为病也，或左或右，胁下有如覆杯，或脐上下如臂，或腹大如盘，令人羸瘦少气，洒淅寒热，嗜卧，饮食不为肌肤，或腹满呕泄，或遇寒则痛。其脉厥而紧，浮而牢，皆积聚之脉也。但牢强急者生，虚弱急者不可治。[24p]

Ji Sheng Fang
Song Dynasty - Yan Yonghe

Seven Hernias

Chao Shi says: A hernia is painful and is caused by weakness of the vital and protective energies. An imbalance in diet, whether too cold or too warm, leads to the invasion of cold and evil qi, which enter the abdomen and result in various hernias. When it occurs, there is pain in the lower abdomen, which may circle around the navel or rise to the heart, causing heart and back pain. In severe cases, there may be cold limbs, spontaneous sweating, nausea, and difficulty in bowel movements. Generally, the pulse associated with hernias is taut and tight, indicative of cold and pain. There are seven types of hernias: knot hernia, symptom hernia, cold hernia, qi hernia, disk hernia, attaching hernia, and wolf hernia. How do we define them? Knot hernia presents as heart pain with cold feet and vomiting after eating; symptom hernia is characterized by sudden fullness in the abdomen with gas accumulation like an arm; cold hernia occurs due to cold food and drink, resulting in sudden pain in the abdomen; qi hernia features intermittent fullness and pain in the abdomen; disk hernia causes pain in the abdomen that radiates to the sides of the navel; attaching hernia has pain in the abdomen linked to below the navel with accumulation; wolf hernia causes pain in the lower abdomen connected to the genital area. If hernias do not heal, evil qi remains trapped, leading to accumulation. As for this disease, whether on the left or right side, there may be a sensation like a cup covering the area, or fullness above and below the navel like an arm, or abdominal distension resembling a plate, resulting in emaciation and shortness of breath, chills, alternating cold and heat, a preference for lying down, and ineffective food intake or abdominal fullness with vomiting and diarrhea, with pain triggered by cold. The pulse is constricted and tight, floating and firm, indicative of accumulation. However, a strong and urgent pulse indicates life, while a weak and urgent pulse is difficult to treat.[24p]

　　　　　阴(疒颓)

　　夫阴(疒颓)之证有四种：一曰肠(疒颓)，二曰气(疒颓)，三曰卵胀，四曰水(疒颓)是也。《圣惠》云：肾气虚，风冷所侵，流入于肾，不能宣散而然也。《三因》云：阴(疒颓)属肝，系宗筋，胃阳明养之。考之众论，俱为至当。多由不自卫生，房室过度，久蓄忧思恐怒之气，或坐卧冷湿处，或劳役无节，皆能致之。病则卵核肿胀，偏有大小，或坚硬如石，或脐腹绞痛，甚则肤囊肿胀，多成疮毒，轻则时出黄水，甚则成痈溃烂。大抵卵胀、肠(疒颓)皆不易治，气(疒颓)、水(疒颓)灸之易愈也。又有小儿有生以来便如此者，乃宿疾也。四(疒颓)治法，橘核丸用之屡验。[25p]

The symptoms of Yin (Tui) can be classified into four types: the first is intestinal (Tui), the second is Qi (Tui), the third is swelling of the eggs, and the fourth is water (Tui). The "Shenghui" states: the kidney Qi is deficient, invaded by wind and cold, flowing into the kidneys, unable to disperse, leading to this condition. The "Sanyin" indicates that Yin (Tui) is associated with the liver and connects with the tendons, while the stomach's Yangming nourishes it. In reviewing numerous texts, they all affirm this view. Many cases arise from poor personal hygiene, excessive sexual activity, prolonged accumulation of emotions such as worry, fear, and anger, sitting or lying in cold and damp places, or overexertion without moderation; all these can lead to this condition. When ill, symptoms include swelling of the egg and cysts, which may vary in size, may be hard as stone, or cause twisting pain in the abdomen; in severe cases, there may be skin abscesses or swelling, leading to sores and toxic conditions. If mild, clear fluid may appear intermittently; in severe cases, there may be festering and decay. Generally speaking, swelling of the eggs and intestinal (Tui) conditions are difficult to treat, while Qi (Tui) and water (Tui) are easier to heal with moxibustion. Additionally, there are cases where children have had this condition since birth, which indicates a chronic illness. The treatment method for the fourth type involves the use of Juzi kernel pills, which have proven effective repeatedly.[25p]

　　　　疮疡全书 【金　窦汉卿】

　　　　　肾痈

　　此毒年高者，因宿有疝气疾，及感冒寒湿气，辛勤；少壮为因房事所得。初起阴囊赤肿，身发寒热，攻水道、归来二穴，痛不可忍，用手按之，皮宽不急，可用败毒散加入当归须、川楝子发散。用手按之急胀似火之热，急用阴囊毒之药治之，更服黄矾丸。　　倘或开刀，须待其熟，以油头绳扎住肾子，以小刀开海底穴，其脓血即流尽矣。外贴金丝等膏。少劳戒色，并避汤火风气及诸毒物。[26p]

Kidney Abscess

This condition occurs in older individuals with a history of hernias, or in those affected by cold and dampness, due to overexertion; in younger people, it often results from sexual activity. Initially, there is redness and swelling of the scrotum, accompanied by chills and fever. Pain intensifies in the water passage and the two lower orifices, making it unbearable. When pressed, the skin feels loose and does not tighten. One can apply a remedy to dispel toxins, such as a mixture of Radix Angelicae Sinensis and Fructus Meliae, for dispersal. If pressing the area feels like fire and there is acute swelling, one must urgently use medications for scrotal toxicity and take lead sulfate pills.

If surgery is necessary, it must wait until the abscess is mature. One should tie off the kidney with an oiled thread and incision at the lowest point; this will allow pus and blood to drain completely. An external application of medicated plasters, such as Jin Si, is recommended. It is advisable to minimize physical labor, avoid sexual activity, and stay away from hot, humid environments and various toxic substances.[26p]

　　　　　阴囊毒 【即外肾痈】

　　此证因肝经湿热不利，遂流毒于膀胱肾经，感冒寒暑邪气，偏盛于阴之经络，以致血气凝聚，寒湿不散，阴囊上肿而痛，或溃烂皮脱，肾子悬挂，宜用泻肝清热汤服之，外用铁箍散围之。　　此证腐坏，急用乌金散敷之。或溃烂，饮食少思，日晡发热，急服加味小柴胡汤。痛甚加黄连，小便不利加木通、车前子，口渴加天花粉、麦门冬、五味子。
　　　　　阴蚀疮

　　阴蚀疮之生，皆由脏中虚怯，肾气衰少，风邪入腑，毒恶损伤荣卫，或与有毒妇人交接，不曾洗净。故时痛时痒，以渐成窍作疳，脓水涌流。若不早治，命亦难保。先用蛇床子、地骨皮、桑槐枝煎汤温洗，内服清热消疳解毒汤，外用掺药。先用金丝膏，后用紫金膏，拔出毒水，易能长肉。　　夫阴蚀疮者，即下疳也。阴汗臊臭，故茎根生疳疮。乃肝经所属之分野。　　内外蛀疳，身热，小便濇滞，宜服小柴胡汤加龙胆草、黄连、车前子。[27p]

Toxic Scrotum (i.e., External Kidney Abscess)

This condition arises from the stagnation of damp-heat in the liver channel, which then flows toxins into the bladder and kidney channels. Exposure to cold and heat pathogens, particularly affecting the yin meridians, leads to the coagulation of blood and qi. Cold and dampness do not disperse, resulting in swelling and pain of the scrotum, or even ulceration and skin peeling, with the testicles hanging low. It is advisable to use a cooling liver disharmonization soup for internal consumption and apply Tie Gu San externally. If there is decay, urgently apply Wu Jin San. If ulceration occurs, with reduced appetite and thoughts of food, afternoon fevers may arise; quickly take an enhanced version of Xiao Chai Hu Tang. For severe pain, add Huang Lian; for difficulty in urination, add Mu Tong and Che Qian Zi; for thirst, add Tian Hua Fen, Mai Men Dong, and Wu Wei Zi.

Yin Erosion Ulcer

The emergence of yin erosion ulcers is due to internal organ weakness, diminished kidney qi, and the invasion of wind pathogens affecting the bowels. These toxins harm the defensive and nourishing aspects, or result from unclean contact with toxic women. Symptoms include intermittent pain and itching, gradually resulting in the formation of sores that discharge pus. If not treated promptly, life may be endangered. First, use She Chuang Zi, Di Gu Pi, and Sang Huai branches to make a warming wash. Internally, consume a clearing heat and detoxifying soup, and use medicinal powders externally. Initially apply Jin Si Gao, followed by Zi Jin Gao to draw out the toxic fluid and promote flesh regrowth. Yin erosion ulcers are indeed the same as lower sores. They may emit a foul odor, which is why the base of the shaft develops sores. These are associated with the liver channel’s territories. For both internal and external erosion sores, with body heat and slow urination, it is advisable to take Xiao Chai Hu Tang with added Long Dan Cao, Huang Lian, and Che Qian Zi.[27p]

　　　　　左右便毒 【又名血疝】

　　夫便毒者，生于小腹两腿合缝之间。或行路远涉辛苦，或上或下低闪肭气，或房事所伤，或男女大欲，不得直遂其志，故败精滞血，留聚中途；或梦寐之间而不泄，或妄想不能忘情息念，故结成毒。然肾者作强之官，伎巧所出，一有所感，精血凝滞，此证遂生。初起之时，寒热交作，两腿牵绊，肿起不能屈伸，乃证之渐也。急服龙胆汤。
　　　　　小肠流注

　　此证受在心经伏热，结聚成毒也。当用败毒流气饮，再服清心流气饮治之，时服腊矾丸。[28p]

Poison in the Lower Body (also known as Blood Hernia)

The condition of poison is located between the legs in the lower abdomen. It may arise from long journeys causing fatigue, from straining while standing or bending, from injuries during intimate relations, or from excessive desire between men and women, leading to an inability to fulfill one's wishes and resulting in the stagnation of essence and blood. This can also happen from not releasing it in dreams, or from unending thoughts and emotions, thus forming poison. The kidneys are the organs of strength and creativity; when stimulated, essence and blood can stagnate, leading to this condition. Initially, symptoms may present as alternating chills and fever, with tension in the legs and swelling that prevents movement, indicating the progression of the ailment. It is urgent to take Long Dan Decoction.

Small Intestine Flow Poison

This condition arises from retained heat in the heart, which accumulates into poison. It is advisable to use the Anti-Poison and Flow Qi Decoction, followed by the Clear Heart and Flow Qi Decoction for treatment, and to regularly take the Chinese Alum Pill.[28p]

　　　　河间六书 【金　刘完素】

　　　　　(疒颓)疝

　　(疒颓)疝，少腹控卵，肿急绞痛也。寒主拘缩，寒极而土化治之，故肿满。经言丈夫(疒颓)疝，谓阴器连少腹急痛。其妇人少腹肿，皆肝足厥阴脉之为病。经注曰：寒气聚而为疝也。又按《难经》言五脏皆有疝，但脉急也。注言脉急者，寒之象。然寒则脉当短小而迟，今言急者，非急数而洪也。由紧脉主痛，急为痛甚。病寒虽急，亦短小也。所以有痛而脉紧急者，脉为心之所养也。凡六气而痛则心神不宁，而紧急不得舒缓，故脉亦从之而见。欲知何气为其痛，当适其紧急相兼之脉而可知。如紧急洪数，则为热痛之类。又经言脾传之肾，病名曰疝瘕，少腹烦冤而痛，出白液，一名曰蛊。注言少腹痛，溲出白液也。一作客热内结，销烁脂肉如虫之食，故名曰蛊也。然经之复言热为疝瘕，则亦不可止言为寒，当以脉证别之。[29p]

Hedong Six Writings by Liu Wansuo (Jin)

(Nèituó) Hernia

(Nèituó) hernia refers to the condition of the lower abdomen where there is swelling and acute cramping pain. Cold causes contraction, and when cold reaches its extreme, it transforms into a condition that can be treated with earth, hence causing swelling. The texts say that in men, (nèituó) hernia manifests as acute pain in the lower abdomen associated with the genitals. In women, swelling in the lower abdomen is due to diseases of the liver channel. The classic commentary states that hernia is caused by the accumulation of cold. Additionally, according to the "Nanjing," all five organs can have hernias, but these are characterized by a rapid pulse. It is noted that a rapid pulse indicates a sign of cold. However, cold should lead to a short, small, and slow pulse; thus, the term "rapid" here does not mean fast and numerous but rather indicates fullness. A tense pulse indicates severe pain, and although cold may be present, it is characterized by a short and small pulse. Therefore, in cases of pain with a tense and rapid pulse, the pulse reflects nourishment from the heart. Whenever there are six qi (elements) involved in the pain, the heart and spirit are unsettled, and the tension cannot relax, leading to observable pulse changes. To understand which qi causes the pain, one must consider the pulse that combines tightness and rapidity. If the pulse is tight and rapid, it indicates heat-related pain. The classic also states that the spleen transmits to the kidneys, with the condition referred to as hernia and masses, characterized by discomfort and pain in the lower abdomen, producing white fluid, hence the name "gu." The commentary notes that pain in the lower abdomen can lead to white fluid excretion. One interpretation states that internal heat can become constipated, causing the loss of fat like a worm consuming it, hence the name "gu." However, since the texts repeatedly identify heat as a potential cause of hernia and masses, it should not be assumed to be solely due to cold; differentiation must be made based on pulse and symptoms.[29p]

　　　　　小肠气

　　《甲乙经》云：小肠病结于腰，上而不下，痛冲心肺邪所系，茴香楝实丸主之。
　　　　　阴疝

　　足厥阴之脉，环阴器，抵小腹。肿或痛，肾虚寒水涸，宜泻邪补脉为治，蒺藜汤主之。　　　　　蛊疝

　　脾风传肾，一名疝气，小腹痛出白液，名曰蛊。《左传》云，以丧志名为蛊病，乃真精不守也。大建中汤主之。
　　　　　心疝

　　心脉急，小腹有形，心不受邪，必传于腑，故小腹有形，心气逆不顺则痛不已，当兼心气治。不止，为有寒邪所中。木香散主之。[30p]

Small Intestine Qi

The "Jia Yi Jing" states: When small intestine disease is lodged in the waist, it rises without descending, causing pain that affects the heart and lungs. The main treatment is the Fennel and Melia fruit pills.

Yin Hernia

The pulse of the Foot Jueyin circulates around the reproductive organs and reaches the lower abdomen. If there is swelling or pain, it indicates cold and deficiency of the kidneys and drying up of fluids. The treatment should involve expelling the evil and nourishing the pulse, with the main prescription being the Jizhi Decoction.

Gu Hernia

Spleen wind transmits to the kidneys, also known as hernia qi. This results in lower abdominal pain and discharge of white fluid, termed Gu. The "Zuo Zhuan" states that when one loses their ambition, it is referred to as Gu disease, which indicates that vital essence is not being conserved. The primary treatment is the Da Jianzhong Decoction.

Heart Hernia

When the heart pulse is urgent and there is a tangible presence in the lower abdomen, while the heart itself is not affected by evil, it must be transmitted to the bowels. Thus, the physical manifestation in the lower abdomen occurs, and if the heart qi is disrupted and has reversed flow, the pain persists. Treatment should also address heart qi. If it continues, it is due to invasion by cold evil. The primary prescription is the Mu Xiang San.[30p]

　　　　儒门事亲 【元　张从政】

　　　　　茎中痛

　　茎中痛者，先宜清剂、寒剂夺之，后以淡剂、甘剂分之。
　　　　　疝本肝经宜通勿塞论

　　疝有七，前人论者甚多，非《灵枢》、《素问》、《铜人》之论，余皆不取。非余好异也，但要穷其源耳。七疝者何？寒疝、水疝、筋疝、血疝、气疝、狐疝、(疒颓)疝，是谓七疝。俗工不识，因立谬名。或曰膀胱，或曰肾冷，或曰小肠气，小儿曰偏气，立名既谬，并丧其实。何哉？盖医者既断为膀胱肾冷小肠气，又曰虚寒所致。其药之用也，不鹿茸、巴戟，则杜仲、苁蓉；不附子、乌头，则干姜、官桂；不楝实、蘹香，则金铃、补骨脂。朝吐暮饵，曾无殊效。三二十年，牢不可去。间因微病，稍似开通。执此微芒，浸成大错。标既不除，本必归甚。处处相传，曾无觉者。岂知诸疝皆归肝经，其奈通流归之小肠脬囊。夫膀胱水腑，专司渗泄；小肠水道，专主通流；肾为少阴，总统二水。[31p]

The Confucian Way of Filial Piety 【Yuan　Zhang Congzheng】

Pain in the Stalk

For pain in the stalk, it is advisable first to use clearing and cold remedies to dispel it, and then to apply mild and sweet remedies to differentiate it.

On Hernias, Which Are Fundamental to the Liver Meridian

There are seven types of hernia; many have discussed them, but I do not accept the views that are not from the "Lingshu," "Suwen," or "Copper Man." It is not that I favor unusual opinions, but I simply wish to uncover the source. What are the seven hernias? They are cold hernia, water hernia, tendon hernia, blood hernia, air hernia, fox hernia, and (sick exhaustion) hernia, which are known as the seven hernias. Common practitioners do not recognize these, thus they create erroneous names. Some say it is the bladder, others say it is cold in the kidneys, or that it is gas in the small intestine; children call it irregular gas. Such misnamed conditions lead to losing the essence of the issue. Why is this? It is because physicians mistakenly classify it as bladder, kidney, or small intestine gas, and also claim it is caused by deficiency and cold. The remedies used are often either deer antler or Ba Jiao, or they switch to Du Zhong and Cong Rong; instead of Fu Zi or Wu Tou, they may use dried ginger or cinnamon; and instead of Huang Lian or Ling Xiang, they might opt for Jin Ling or Bu Gu Zhi. Morning and evening they take these with no significant effect. Over three to twenty years, it remains firmly entrenched. Occasionally, when minor illness occurs, it may seem to alleviate slightly. Holding onto this slight improvement leads to a major misconception. If the marked issue is not resolved, it will inevitably return with greater severity. Tales of this spread everywhere, with no one aware of the truth. Little do they know that all hernias are related to the liver meridian, whose flow ultimately leads to the small intestine and its pouch. The bladder, being a water organ, is responsible for drainage; the small intestine, as a water channel, governs flow; and the kidneys, being associated with the lesser yin, oversee both types of water.
[31p]

人之小溲，自胃入小肠，渗入膀胱。膀胱者，脬囊也，气化则水出茎端，此常道也。及其为疝，乃属足厥阴肝经。盖环阴器而上入小腹者，足厥阴肝经也。夫肝肾皆属于下，与冲、任、督相附。然《灵枢经》言：足厥阴肝经病，则有遗溺、癃闭、狐疝。专主肾与膀胱、小肠三经，则不言疝，是受疝之处，乃肝之部分也。且《内经》言：男子宗筋为束骨之会。而肝专主筋。睾者，囊中之丸。虽主外肾，非厥阴环而引之，则玉茎无由伸缩。在女子则为篡户，其内外为二：其一曰廷孔，其二曰窈漏。此足厥阴与冲、任、督之所会也。《灵枢》言：足厥阴之经筋，聚于阴器。其病伤于寒则阴缩入，伤于热则纵挺不收，治在行水清阴气。故阳明与太阴、厥阴之筋，皆会于阴器。惟厥阴主筋，故为疝者，必本之厥阴。[32p]

The small urine of a person enters the small intestine from the stomach and seeps into the bladder. The bladder is a sac for liquid; when it transforms, water exits from the tip, which is the common principle. When it forms a hernia, it belongs to the liver channel of the foot (Jueyin). This channel circles around the genital area and enters the lower abdomen. Both the liver and kidneys are associated with the lower parts, connecting with the Chong, Ren, and Du vessels. Yet, the "Lingshu" states that diseases of the liver channel of the foot can lead to incontinence, urinary obstruction, and hernia. It specifically governs the kidney, bladder, and small intestine channels, thus not mentioning hernia, indicating that the site of hernia is part of the liver. Furthermore, the "Neijing" states that in men, the zong muscle is the meeting of the bones. The liver primarily governs muscles. The testicle is the orb within the sac. Although it primarily governs the external kidney, if not guided by the Jueyin channel, the jade stem cannot expand or contract. In women, it is the genital opening, with inner and outer parts: one is called the ting hole and the other is the yao leak. These are where the foot Jueyin meets the Chong, Ren, and Du vessels. The "Lingshu" states that the channel of the foot Jueyin converges at the genital area. If it is injured by cold, it retracts; if injured by heat, it protrudes without control. The treatment lies in promoting water to clear the yin Qi. Therefore, the channels of Yangming, Taiyin, and Jueyin all converge at the genital area. Only the Jueyin governs the muscles, thus if a hernia occurs, it must originate from the Jueyin.[32p]

《灵枢》又言：足厥阴之别，名曰蠡沟，去内踝五寸，别走少阳，循胫上睾，结于茎。其病气逆睾肿卒疝，实则挺长，虚则暴痒，取之所别也。岂非厥阴为受病之处耶？《灵枢》又言：邪在小肠，连睾系，属于肾，贯肝络肺。心系气盛，厥逆上冲，肠胃熏肝，散于肓，结于脐。故取之肓原以散之，取太阴以平之，取厥阴以下之，取巨虚、下廉以去之，按其所过之经以调之。此其初虽言邪在小肠，至其治法，必曰取厥阴以下之，乃知诸疝关于厥阴，可以无疑。以脉考之，《素问》云，厥阴滑为狐风疝，少阳滑为肺风疝，太阴滑为脾风疝，阳明滑为心风疝，太阳滑为肾风疝，少阴滑为肝风疝。凡此六疝，虽见于他脉中，皆言风疝者，足厥阴肝经之气也。《灵枢》亦曰，心脉微滑为心疝，肝脉滑甚为(疒贵)疝，肾脉滑甚为癃(疒贵)。凡此三脏脉之疝，亦以滑为疝也。[33p]

The “Lingshu” also states: The differentiation of the foot Jueyin is called Li Gou, located five cun above the inner ankle. It branches off to travel to Shaoyang, following the leg up to the testicles, and connects at the root. When pathogenic qi reverses, it causes testicular swelling and sudden hernias; if it is full, it is elongated, and if it is deficient, it causes severe itching—this is the place where it branches off. Is it not true that Jueyin is the location affected by illness?

The “Lingshu” further states: When the evil is in the small intestine, it is connected to the testicular system, belongs to the kidney, and penetrates through the liver's network to the lung. The heart is linked to abundant qi, which rises and clashes upward; the intestines and stomach disturb the liver, scattered in the diaphragm and settled at the navel. Therefore, we approach the diaphragm to disperse it, address the Taiyin to pacify it, utilize areas below Jueyin, and apply pressure on Ju Xu and Xia Lian to eliminate it, adjusting according to the meridians it passes through.

Though it initially states the evil is in the small intestine, in the treatment method, it must mention focusing on areas below Jueyin, thus knowing that all hernias relate to Jueyin, inevitably. Consulting the pulse, the “Suwen” mentions that Jueyin slippery indicates fox wind hernias, Shaoyang slippery indicates lung wind hernias, Taiyin slippery indicates spleen wind hernias, Yangming slippery indicates heart wind hernias, Taiyang slippery indicates kidney wind hernias, and Shaoyin slippery indicates liver wind hernias. All six hernias, even if seen in other pulses, are said to be wind hernias of the foot Jueyin liver meridian.

The “Lingshu” also states that a slightly slippery heart pulse indicates heart hernia, a very slippery liver pulse signifies (zang gui) hernia, and a very slippery kidney pulse indicates (zang gui). All these three organ hernias are also characterized by slippage as a sign of hernia.[33p]

《素问》又云，脉大急皆为疝。心脉滑，传为心疝。肺脉沉，传为肺疝。三阴急为疝，三阳急为瘕。王太仆云，太阳受寒，血凝为瘕；太阴受寒，气聚为疝。此言太阴受寒，传之肝经，可以温药逐之，而不可以温药补之。若补之者，是欲病去而强挽留之也。历考《素问》，三阳为病发寒热，其传为(疒颓)疝。此亦言膀胱非受病之处，必传于厥阴部分，然后为疝也。又言，病在少腹，腹痛，不得大小便，病名曰疝，得之寒。言脉急者曰疝瘕，少腹痛。凡言少腹者，岂非厥阴之部分耶？又言：脾风传胃名曰疝瘕，此谓非肝木不能为风气。名曰厥疝，盖脾土虚而不能制水，又为肝木所凌也。又言督脉为冲疝，盖厥阴与冲、任、督俱会于前阴也。岂不明哉？至如运气中又言，岁太阳在泉，寒淫所胜，民病少腹控睾。盖寒客于小肠、膀胱，则肝木缩而不得伸，此母传之子也。[34p]

The "Plain Questions" also states that a large, rapid pulse indicates hernia. A slippery heart pulse is indicative of heart hernia. A deep lung pulse suggests lung hernia. Rapid pulses in the three Yin indicate hernia, while rapid pulses in the three Yang indicate masses (jias). Wang Taifu said, when the Taiyang experiences cold, blood congeals to form a mass; when the Taiyin experiences cold, qi gathers to form a hernia. It is said that when the Taiyin is affected by cold, it transmits to the liver channel, which can be treated with warming herbs to expel it, but not with nourishing herbs. If one dares to nourish it, it is akin to wanting the illness to leave yet forcefully keeping it. Upon examining "Plain Questions," it becomes clear that the three Yang diseases manifest as cold and heat, leading to hernia. This indicates that the bladder is not the site of the disease but rather transmits to the Jueyin area, resulting in hernia. Furthermore, it states that if the disease is located in the lower abdomen, causing abdominal pain and inability to urinate or defecate, it is termed hernia, resulting from cold. When the pulse is rapid, it indicates hernia and mass, along with pain in the lower abdomen. When referring to the lower abdomen, is it not the Jueyin region? It is also stated that spleen wind transmits to the stomach, referred to as hernia or mass, suggesting that the liver wood cannot generate wind qi. This is termed Jue hernia, as the spleen earth is deficient and cannot control water, being further weakened by the liver wood. It is also mentioned that the governing vessel corresponds to the chong hernia, as Jueyin intersects with the chong, ren, and governing vessels in the front yin. Is this not clear? As for the movements of qi, it is mentioned that during the year when the Taiyang descends into the springs, cold prevails, causing the people to suffer from pain in the lower abdomen and groin. This occurs because cold invades the small intestine and bladder, causing the liver wood to shrink and become unable to extend; this is the mother transmitting to the child.[34p]

阳明司天，燥淫所胜，丈夫(疒颓)疝，妇人少腹痛。此言肝气不得上行，为金所抑，鬼贼故也。又言，太阴在泉，土胜则寒气逆满，食饮不下，甚则为疝。此亦言寒客太阴湿土，土不胜水，水传之肝经也。又尝遍阅《铜人》俞穴，亦相表里。如背上十三椎俞，肝经言寒疝。腹部中行，惟阴交一穴寒疝言，任脉之所发也；关元一穴言暴疝，小肠之募，足三阴任脉之会也；中极一穴言疝瘕，膀胱之募，亦足三阴任脉之会也；曲骨一穴言(疒贵)疝，任脉、足厥阴之会也。其腹部第二行，肓腧二穴言寒疝，冲脉足少阴之会也；四满二穴言疝瘕，冲、任脉、足少阴肾之会也。其腹部第三行，大巨二穴言(疒贵)疝，足阳明脉气之所发也；气冲二穴言(疒颓)疝，茎中痛两丸寒痛，亦足阳明脉气之所发也。[35p]

Yangming governs the heavens; dryness overcomes the excessive moisture, causing men to suffer from testicular hernias and women from lower abdominal pain. This indicates that liver qi cannot ascend and is suppressed by metal, hence the affliction. Additionally, when the Taiyin is at the spring and the earth prevails, cold qi reverses and fills, leading to inability to digest food and drink, which can severely result in hernias. This reflects the cold invading the Taiyin's damp earth, causing the earth to be unable to overcome water, which impacts the liver meridian.

I have also extensively reviewed the "Copper Man" and the associated points, which reflect outward and inward relations. For example, at the back, the thirteen Shu points indicate cold hernia affecting the liver meridian. In the abdominal region, the Yin Jiao point is noted for cold hernia, being an expression of the Ren meridian; the Guan Yuan point indicates sudden hernia, associated with the small intestine's reserve and the convergence of the three Yin meridians; the Zhong Ji point refers to hernia and masses, being the reserve of the bladder and also the convergence of the three Yin meridians; and the Qu Gu point relates to hernia and is associated with both the Ren meridian and the Foot Jueyin.

In the second abdominal segment, the Huang Shu points denote cold hernia, being the convergence of the Chong and Foot Shaoyin; the Si Man points reflect hernia and masses, relating to the Chong and Ren meridians and the Foot Shaoyin kidney. In the third abdominal segment, the Da Ju points refer to hernia, arising from the energy of the Foot Yangming meridian; the Qi Chong points indicate testicular hernia, with pain in the scrotum and cold pain in the two testicles, also arising from the energy of the Foot Yangming meridian.[35p]

其腹部第四行，府舍二穴言疝痛，足太阴、厥阴、阴维之交会也；冲门二穴言阴疝，足太阴、厥阴之会也。其在侧胁者，五枢二穴言寒疝，阴邪上入少腹，带脉下三寸也。其在足六经者，足厥阴穴十名，言疝者七，谓大敦、行间、太冲、中封、蠡沟、中都、曲泉。足少阳穴十四名，言疝者一，谓丘墟穴也。足太阴穴十一名，言疝者一，谓阴陵泉也。足阳明穴十五名，言疝者一，谓阴市穴也。足少阴穴十名，言疝者五，谓然谷、太溪、照海、交信、筑宾也。足太阳穴十八名，言疝者二，谓金门、合阳也。由是言之，惟厥阴言疝独多，为疝之主也。其他经穴，虽亦治疝，终非受疝之地，但与足厥阴相连耳。或在泉寒胜，木气挛缩禁于此经；或司天燥胜，木气抑郁于此经；或忿怒悲哀，忧抑顿挫，结于此经；或药淋外固，闭尾缩精，壅于此经。其病差别如此。[36p]

In the fourth row of the abdomen, the two points of the palace mention hernia pain, where the foot Taiyin, Jueyin, and Yinwei converge; the two points of Chongmen mention the Yin hernia, where the foot Taiyin and Jueyin meet. For those on the side of the ribs, the two points of Wushu mention cold hernia, where Yin evil rises into the lower abdomen, three inches below the Dai vessel. In the six channels of the foot, the ten points of the foot Jueyin mention hernia seven times, namely Dadu, Xingjian, Taichong, Zhongfeng, Ligou, Zhongdu, and Qusuan. The fourteen points of the foot Shaoyang mention hernia once, specifically Qiusu point. The eleven points of the foot Taiyin mention hernia once, namely Yinlingquan. The fifteen points of the foot Yangming mention hernia once, specifically Yinshi point. The ten points of the foot Shaoyin mention hernia five times, namely Rangu, Taixi, Zhaohai, Jiaoxin, and Zhubin. The eighteen points of the foot Taiyang mention hernia twice, specifically Jindmen and Heyang. Thus, it can be said that only Jueyin mentions hernia frequently, being the main point for hernia. Other meridian points, although they also treat hernia, are ultimately not the locations that receive hernia, but are merely connected to the foot Jueyin. This may be due to cold stagnation in the Qi, wood energy being constricted in this meridian; or due to dryness in the skies, where wood energy is depressed in this meridian; or due to anger, sorrow, and anxiety causing blockages in this meridian; or due to medication externally solidifying, closing the tail and retracting essence, obstructing in this meridian. The conditions of the illness differ in this way.[36p]

不知世间之方多热补，信俗方则《素问》、《灵枢》、《铜人》非也，信《素问》、《灵枢》、《铜人》则俗方非也。呜呼！余立于医四十余岁，识练日久，因经识病，然后不惑。且夫遣溺闭癃，阴痿脬痹，精滑白淫，皆男子之疝也，不可妄归之肾冷。血涸不月，月罢腰膝上热，足躄，嗌干，癃闭，少腹有块，或定或移，前阴突出，后阴痔核，皆女子之疝也。但女子不谓之疝，而曰瘕。若少年得之，不计男子、妇人皆无子。故隐蔽委曲之事，了不干脬、肾、小肠之事，乃足厥阴肝经之职也。俗方止言脬、肾、小肠，殊不言肝木一句，惑人甚矣。且肝经乙木也，木属东方，为心火之母也。凡疝者，非肝木受邪，则肝木自甚也，不可便言虚而补之。《难经》所谓东方实，西方虚，泻南方，补北方。此言泻火，木自平，金自清，水自旺也。[37p]

In this world, one does not understand the many remedies common folk use. If one trusts common remedies, then the "Suwen," "Ling Shu," and "Bronze Man" are not valid; if one trusts the "Suwen," "Ling Shu," and "Bronze Man," then common remedies are not valid either. Alas! I have been in the medical field for over forty years, and through long practice have come to recognize illnesses, thus I am no longer confused. Furthermore, conditions such as dysuria, urinary retention, impotence, and excessive sexual desire are all male ailments—not merely due to cold in the kidneys. If there is blood deficiency and the menstrual cycle does not occur, leading to heat in the lower back and knees, foot cramps, throat dryness, urinary retention, abdominal masses that may be fixed or mobile, protrusion of the front or hemorrhoids at the back, these are all female ailments. Yet, women do not call these conditions hernias; they refer to them as masses. If a young person suffers from these, it matters not whether they are male or female, for they will be without offspring. Such hidden and intricate matters have nothing to do with the bladder, kidneys, or intestines; they are the responsibility of the Liver Channel of the Jueyin. Common remedies only speak of the bladder, kidneys, and intestines, completely neglecting the aspect of Liver Wood, which is profoundly misleading. Moreover, the Liver Channel corresponds to the Wood element, which belongs to the East and is the mother of Heart Fire. In general, hernias arise when Liver Wood is invaded by pathogens, or when the Liver Wood itself becomes excessive; one must not hastily claim deficiency and simply supplement. The "Nanjing" states that the East is solid, the West is void; one purges the South and supplements the North. This refers to purging fire, balancing Wood, clarifying Metal, and strengthening Water.[37p]

昔审言为蔡之参军也，因坐湿地，疝痛不可堪，诸药莫救。余急以导水丸、禹功散泻三十余行，肿立消，痛立减。又项关一男子病卒疝，暴痛不任，倒于街衢，人莫能动，呼予救之。余引经证之邪气客于足厥阴之络，令人卒疝，故病阴丸痛也。余急泻大敦二穴，大痛立已。夫大敦穴者，乃足厥阴之二穴也。殄寇镇一夫病(疒皆)疟发渴，痛饮蜜浆，剧伤冰水。医者莫知泻去其湿，反杂进姜附，湿为躁热所壅，三焦闭溢，水道不行，阴道不兴，阴囊肿坠，大于升斗。余先以导水百余丸，少顷，以猪肾散投之。是夜，泻青赤水一斗，遂失痛之所在。又一夫病卒疝，赤肿大痛，数日不止，诸药如水投石。余以导水一百五十丸，令三次咽之；次以通经散三钱，空腹淡酒调下。五更，下脏腑壅积之物数行，痛肿皆去，不三日平复如故。《内经》曰，木郁则达之，谓吐之令条达也。肝积本当吐，然观其病之上下，以顺为贵。仲景所谓上宜吐，下宜泻也。[38p]

In the past, when Shen Yan was an army officer in Cai, he sat in a damp place and suffered unbearable testicular pain, for which no medicine could provide relief. I hastily administered over thirty doses of water-guiding pills and Yu Gong powder, which quickly alleviated the swelling and reduced the pain.

There was also a man with acute testicular pain who collapsed in the street, and no one could help him. He called for my assistance. I referred to the texts and identified the evil qi residing in the meridian of the foot's jueyin, which causes sudden testicular pain; hence, I used Yin Wan for the pain. I quickly drained the two acupoints of Dadu, and the severe pain immediately ceased. The Dadu acupoint is indeed one of the two points of the foot's jueyin.

There was a man in Diao Kou who suffered from a fever with thirst, and his craving for honeyed drinks resulted in extreme injury from ice water. The physicians were unaware that they needed to drain the excess moisture and instead compounded with ginger, causing dampness to be trapped and turning into heat, leading to blockages in the three burners, impaired water pathways, and sluggishness in the reproductive channels, resulting in a swollen scrotum, larger than a ladle. I first administered over a hundred water-guiding pills, and soon after, I used pig kidney powder. That night, he expelled a bucket of dark and light-colored water, and thus the pain at that site was relieved.

Another man had acute testicular pain with pronounced swelling that persisted for several days; all medications acted as if they were thrown into water without effect. I gave him one hundred fifty water-guiding pills for three doses and followed with three qian of Tongjing powder mixed with light wine on an empty stomach. By dawn, he expelled numerous clotted substances from his internal organs, and all pain and swelling disappeared, returning to normal within three days. The "Neijing" states: when the wood is congested, it should be expelled to allow for smooth flow, referring to the requirement to vomit for unblocking. Since the liver accumulates, it should ideally be purged; however, one must consider the nature of the ailment both above and below, with alignment to natural flow being paramount. This aligns with Zhang Zhongjing's assertion that it is appropriate to induce vomiting for conditions above and purging for those below.[38p]

　　　　　七疝病形

　　寒疝，久而无子，其状囊冷，结硬如石，阴茎不举，或控睾丸而痛。得于坐卧湿地，或寒月涉水，或置雨雪，或坐卧砖石，或风冷处，使内过劳。宜以温剂下之。　　水疝，其状肾囊肿痛，阴汗时出，或囊肿而状如水晶，或囊痒而燥出黄水，或少腹中按之作水声。得于饮水醉后，使内过劳，汗出而遇风，寒湿之气，聚于囊中，故水多令人为卒疝。宜以逐水之剂下之。有漏针去水者，人多不得其法。　　筋疝，其状阴茎肿胀，或溃或脓，或痛而里急筋缩，或茎中痛，痛极则痒，或挺纵不收，或白物如精，随溲而下。得于房室劳伤，及邪术所使。宜以降心之剂下之。　　血疝，其状如黄瓜，在大腹两旁，横骨两端约中，俗云便痈。得于重感，春夏大燠，劳动使内，气血流溢，渗入脬囊，留而不去，结成痈肿，脓少血多。宜以和血之剂下之。　　气疝，其状上连肾区，下及阴囊，或因号哭忿怒，则气郁之而胀，怒哭号罢，则气散者是也。[39p]

Forms of Hernia Disease

Cold hernia: If it persists without offspring, the bag feels cold, hard like stone; the penis does not erect, and may cause pain when pressing on the testicles. This occurs from sitting or lying on damp ground, wading through cold water during the cold months, being exposed to rain or snow, sitting or lying on bricks or stones, or in cold windy places, causing excessive internal labor. It is advisable to use warming agents to treat it.

Water hernia: It presents as kidney cyst pain, with occasional sweat from the genitals, or the cyst appears crystal-like, or itchy and discharges yellow fluid, or causes a water sound when pressed on the lower abdomen. This arises from excessive drinking after intoxication, internal strain, sweating and exposure to wind, or cold dampness gathering in the cyst, leading to an overload of water resulting in sudden hernia. It is advised to use diuretic agents for treatment. Few know the method to expel water through a leaking needle.

Muscle hernia: Symptoms include swelling of the penis, which may ulcerate or form pus, along with pain that causes deep muscle contractions, or internal pain that is extremely itchy, or persistent and elongated without retraction, with a discharge resembling semen, flowing with urine. This condition arises from sexual exhaustion or external malevolent practices. It is advisable to use soothing agents to treat the heart.

Blood hernia: It feels like a cucumber on both sides of the lower abdomen, roughly at the midpoint of the hip bones, commonly referred to as "benyong." This occurs due to heavy sensations in spring and summer heat, physical labor causing internal strain, where qi and blood overflow, seeping into the pouch and remaining, forming abscesses, often with pus scarce and blood abundant. It is recommended to use tonifying agents for blood to treat it.

Qi hernia: It presents with connections to the kidney area above and the scrotum below, possibly triggered by crying or anger, causing qi stagnation and swelling; when anger and crying cease, the qi disperses.[39p]

有一治法，以针出气而愈者，然针有得失，宜以散气之药下之。或小儿亦有此疾，俗曰偏气，得于父已年老，或年少多病，阴痿精怯，强力入房，因而有子，胎中病也。此疝不治，惟筑宾一穴主之。　　狐疝，其状如瓦，卧则入小腹，行立则出小腹，入囊中。狐则昼出穴而溺，夜则入穴而不溺。此疝出入上下往来，正与狐相类也。亦与气疝大同小异，今人带钩钤是也。宜以逐气流经之药下之。[40p]

There is a treatment method where one uses needles to release gas for recovery; however, needles have their benefits and drawbacks, so one should also administer medication to disperse the gas. Sometimes children may suffer from this ailment, commonly referred to as '偏气' (side energy), which can arise from a father who is either elderly or a young one who is frequently ill, experiencing issues such as impotence and weak essence. If he forcefully engages in intercourse, it can result in a child, which leads to problems during pregnancy. This hernia, if left untreated, is primarily managed by needling a specific point.

The 'fox hernia' resembles a tile: when lying down, it retracts into the lower abdomen, but when standing or walking, it protrudes from the lower abdomen and enters the scrotum. The fox emerges from its den to urinate during the day and retreats into it at night without needing to urinate. This hernia's entry and exit mimic the behaviors of a fox and have similarities to gas hernias. Nowadays, people use hooked devices for it. It is advisable to administer medication to expel the gas flowing through the channels.[40p]

　　(疒颓)疝，其状阴囊肿缒，如升如斗，不痒不痛者是也。得之地气卑湿所生，故江淮之间，湫塘之处，多感此疾。宜以去湿之药下之。女子阴户突出，虽亦此类，乃热则不禁固也。不可便谓虚寒而濇之燥之补之。本名曰瘕，宜以苦下之，以苦坚之。王冰云：阳气下坠，阴气上争，上争则寒多，下坠则筋缓。故睾垂纵缓，因作(疒颓)疝也。已上七疝，下去其病之后，可调则调，可补则补，各量病势，勿拘俗法。经所谓阴盛而腹胀不通者，(疒颓)癃疝也，故不可不下。[41p]

Shan (a type of hernia) presents as a swelling in the scrotum, similar to a rising or falling form; it is neither itchy nor painful. This condition arises from dampness of the earth, hence it frequently occurs in the Jianghuai region, particularly in low, damp areas. It is advisable to treat it with medicines that dispel dampness. In women, a protrusion at the vulva is also similar, but if associated with heat, it cannot be treated by simply reinforcing or drying it. Its proper name is jia, which should be treated with bitter substances to purge and solidify. Wang Bing states: the downward movement of yang energy leads to the upward contention of yin energy; when there is contention above, there is an excess of cold, and when there is descent below, the tendons become lax. Thus, the hanging of the testicles leads to the occurrence of shan. After addressing the condition of the seven types of shan, treatment can be adjusted or supplemented as needed, based on the severity of the illness, without being strictly bound to conventional methods. The classics state that when yin is dominant and there are abdominal distension and obstruction, it is a case of shan repletion, thus it must not be neglected.[41p]

　　　　　便痈

　　夫便痈者，乃男子之疝也。俗呼为便痈，言于不便处害一痈，故名便痈。便痈者，谬名也，《难》、《素》所不载。然足厥阴肝之经络是气血行流之道路，冲、任、督脉亦属肝经之旁络。《难经》曰：男子有七疝是也。便痈者，血疝也。治之以导水丸、桃仁承气汤，或抵当汤投之，同瘀血不散而治，大作剂料，峻泻一二十行。次以玉烛散和气血通经络之类则是。世只知多用大黄、牡蛎而已，间有不愈者，是不知和血通经之道也。[42p]

Bowel Abscess

Bowel abscess refers to a type of hernia in men. It is commonly called bowel abscess because it harms the affected area, hence the name. However, bowel abscess is a misnomer and is not mentioned in the "Nanjing" or "Suwen." Nonetheless, the pathways of the liver meridian in the foot's Jueyin govern the circulation of Qi and blood, and the Chong, Ren, and Du meridians are also associated with the liver's collateral channels. The "Nanjing" states that men have seven types of hernias, and bowel abscess pertains to blood hernia. It can be treated with Daoshui Pills or Taoren Chengqi Decoction, or by using Diding Decoction to combat stagnant blood that fails to disperse, employing substantial doses for a vigorous purge of one to twenty passages. Subsequently, using Yuzhu Powder to harmonize Qi and blood and open the meridians is advisable. The world only knows the frequent use of Da Huang and Mu Li, and there are cases where recovery does not occur, indicating a lack of knowledge regarding the principles of harmonizing blood and opening the meridians.[42p]

　　　　　下疳

　　夫下疳久不愈者，俗呼曰臊疳是也。先以导水、禹功，先泻肝经；外以木香散掺之，日上三两度；然后服淡粥一二日则止。
　　　　东垣十书 【元　李杲】

　　　　　隐曲不利

　　经曰：二阳之病发心脾，有不得隐曲，女子不月。释之者谓，男子则脾受之而味不化，故少精；女子则心受之而血不流，故不月。分心脾为男女，各受立说。窃独谓不然。夫二阳，阳明也。胃与大肠之脉也。肠胃有病，心脾受之。发心脾，犹言延及于心脾也。虽然，脾胃为合，胃病而及脾，理固宜矣。大肠与心，本非合也。今大肠而及心，何哉？盖胃为受纳之府，大肠为传化之府。[43p]

Soft Chancre

If a soft chancre does not heal for a long time, it is commonly referred to as a "smelly chancre." First, lead out the moisture and drain the liver channel; externally apply a powder of patchouli mixed in, a few times daily. Then, consume plain porridge for one to two days until cessation.

Hidden Disturbance not Beneficial

The classic states: When the two Yang conditions manifest in the heart and spleen, there is hindered obstruction, and women do not menstruate. Those who interpret this say, for men, the spleen is affected and nourishment does not transform, thus leading to deficiency; for women, the heart is affected and blood does not flow, hence the absence of menstruation. They separate the heart and spleen for men and women, each subject to this interpretation. However, I beg to differ. The two Yang refer to Yangming, connected to the stomach and large intestine. When the intestines and stomach are ill, the heart and spleen are also affected. To say they reach the heart and spleen is merely to express the extent of their influence. Nonetheless, the spleen and stomach are related; thus, a stomach ailment affecting the spleen is justifiable. However, the large intestine and heart are not connected; why do disturbances from the large intestine reach the heart? This is because the stomach is the repository of intake, and the large intestine is responsible for transformation and transportation.[43p]

食入于胃浊气归心，饮入于胃输精于脾者，以胃之能纳，大肠之能化也。肠胃既病，则不能受，不能化，心脾何所资乎？心脾既无所资，则无所运化而生精血矣。故肠胃有病，心脾受之，则男为少精，女为不月矣。心脾当总言男女，不当分说，至隐曲、不月方可分说耳。若如释者之言，则男之精独资于脾而不资于心，女之血独资于心而不资于脾，有是理耶？盖男女之精血，皆由五脏之相养而后成。可谓之男精资于脾，女血资于心乎？经本曰：男女皆有心脾之病。但在男子则隐曲不利，在女子则月事不来耳。[44p]

Food ingested into the stomach returns impure energy to the heart, while drink ingested into the stomach is transformed into essence by the spleen; this is due to the stomach's ability to receive and the large intestine's ability to transform. When the intestines and stomach are ill, they cannot receive or transform, so what can the heart and spleen rely on? If the heart and spleen have no resources, then there can be no transformation and the generation of essence and blood will cease. Thus, when the intestines and stomach are ill, the heart and spleen suffer, leading to men producing less essence and women not having their menstruation. The heart and spleen should be discussed in general terms for both men and women, and should not be treated differently except in specific conditions like hidden blockages or missed menstruation. If one were to follow the words of the Buddhist, it would imply that a man's essence relies solely on the spleen and not on the heart, and that a woman's blood relies solely on the heart and not on the spleen. Is there such reasoning? Indeed, the essence and blood of both men and women are nourished by the interaction of the five organs before they are formed. Can it be said that a man's essence relies on the spleen and a woman's blood on the heart? The classics state: both men and women can suffer from heart and spleen ailments. However, in men, this manifests as hidden blockages that are detrimental, while in women, it results in missed menstruation.[44p]

　　　　　论疝

　　前阴分大寒大热，囊垂缩。阴阳别论云：三阳为病发寒热，下为壅肿，及为痿厥腨(疒肙)，其传为索泽，又传为(疒颓)疝。夫热在外寒在内则囊垂，此九夏之气也，寒在外热在内则卵缩，此三冬之气也。足太阳膀胱之脉逆，上迎手太阳、小肠之脉，下行至足厥阴肝之脉，不得伸，其任脉并厥阴之脉逆，则如巨川之水，致阳气下坠。是风寒湿热，下出囊中，致两睾肿大，谓之曰疝，大甚则为(疒颓)。足厥阴之脉，与太阳、膀胱寒水之脉，同至前阴之末。《伤寒论》云：足厥阴肝经为病，烦满囊缩，急下之，宜大承气汤以泻大热。[45p]

Discussion on Hernia

The front yin is affected by extreme cold and heat, leading to the descent and shrinkage of the pouch. The theories of Yin and Yang state that when the three Yangs manifest a disease, it brings cold and heat, resulting in obstructed swelling, or causing paralysis of the intestines (hernia). This condition can manifest as a thickening of the pouch and is commonly referred to as hernia. When heat is external and cold is internal, the pouch descends; this corresponds to the energy of late summer. Conversely, when cold is external and heat is internal, the egg contracts; this corresponds to the energy of mid-winter.

The meridian of the foot's Taiyang bladder ascends, meets the hand's Taiyang and small intestine meridians, and descends to the foot's Jueyin liver meridian, where it is unable to extend. If both the Ren and Jueyin meridians are in rebellion, it is like a mighty river, causing Yang energy to fall. This situation results from wind, cold, dampness, and heat escaping from the pouch, leading to the swelling of both testicles, referred to as hernia; if it is severe, it is termed as "tao" (placement). The Jueyin meridian of the foot, along with the cold water pathways of Taiyang and bladder, reaches the end of the front yin.

The "Treatise on Febrile Diseases" states: When there is illness in the foot Jueyin liver channel, accompanied by fullness and pouch shrinkage, swift treatment is necessary. A large dose of the Chengqi Decoction is advised to purge great heat.[45p]

《灵枢》经筋篇云：足厥阴肝，伤于寒则阴缩入。前说囊缩为大热，此说为大寒。又说：囊缩垂睾，下引(疒颓)疝脚气，为大寒风湿盛，下垂为寒。与上二说不同，何也？曰：以平康不病人论之，夏暑大热，囊卵累垂，冬天大寒，急缩收上，与前三说又不同。何也？曰：伤寒家囊卵缩，大热在内，宜承气汤急下之。与经筋说阴缩入，大寒在外，亦是热在内与伤寒家同。故再引平康人以证之。冬天阳气在内，阴气在外，人亦应之，故寒在外则皮急，皮急则囊缩。夏月阴气在内，阳气在外，人亦应之，故热在外则皮缓，皮缓则囊垂，此(疒颓)疝之象也。三说虽殊，皆一理也。[46p]

The "Ling Shu" states in the chapter on the meridians: The foot jueyin liver, when harmed by cold, causes the yin to contract inward. Previously, it was mentioned that the pouch retracts due to great heat; now it is said to be due to great cold. It also states: The pouch retracts, causing testicular atrophy, leading to conditions like hernias and edema, due to excessive cold and wind dampness, with retraction indicative of cold. This differs from the earlier two statements; why? It is because, when discussing a healthy person, in summer the intense heat causes the pouch and testicles to hang down, while in winter the severe cold causes them to retract. This differs again from the previous three statements; why? It is stated that for those suffering from cold damaging the pouch and testicles, the heat is internal and it is appropriate to administer purgative decoctions to urgently relieve it. This aligns with the theory of the pouch retracting inward from external severe cold, also indicating internal heat, consistent with the cold damage theory. Hence, reference to a healthy person is used for verification. In winter, the yang energy is internal and the yin energy is external, corresponding in people; thus, when cold is external, the skin tightens, leading to pouch retraction. In summer, the yin energy is internal and the yang energy is external; thus, when heat is external, the skin relaxes, leading to pouch hanging down, resembling the condition of hernias and edema. Although the three statements are different, they are all based on a single principle.[46p]

　　　　　论阴疮

　　夫阴疮者，大概有三等：一者湿阴疮；二者妒精疮；三者阴蚀疮，又曰下疳疮。盖湿疮者，由肾经虚弱，风湿相搏，邪气乘之，瘙痒成疮，浸淫汁出，如疥癣者是也。妒精者，由壮年精气盈满，久旷房室，阴上生疮，赤肿作害，妨闷痒痛者是也。阴蚀疮者，由肾脏虚邪，热结下焦，经络否濇，气血不行，或房劳洗浴不洁，以致生疮，隐忍不医，焮肿尤甚，由疮在里，措手无方，疼痛注闷，或小便如淋，阴丸肿痛是也。或经十数日，溃烂血脓，肌肉侵蚀，或血出不止，以成下疳。若身体壮热，烦渴恶寒，宜急治之，以大豆甘草汤渍之，渍毒之汤洗浴之，服五香连翘汤、漏芦汤等疏之，更以截疳抵圣散干掺之，四畔用摩风膏温润之，后以将护忌慎之。渴不止者，服竹叶黄芪汤。大便软者，宜服托里茯苓汤调治之。夫如是则无不差矣。[47p]

On Yin Sores

Yin sores can generally be categorized into three types: the first is damp yin sores; the second is jealousy sores; the third is erosion sores, also known as lower sores. Damp sores are caused by weakness of the kidney channel, where wind and dampness clash, allowing evil qi to take hold, resulting in itchiness and sores with secretions, resembling scabies. Jealousy sores occur when youthful vitality is abundant but overlooked for extended periods, leading to sores on the genitals that are swollen and painful, causing distress and itching. Erosion sores arise from weak kidney energy accompanied by evil forces, with heat accumulating in the lower region, obstructing channels, impeding the flow of qi and blood. Poor hygiene after sexual activity can lead to sores, and if left untreated, they may worsen with severe swelling and internal pain, resulting in difficulty urinating or painful swelling of the genitals. After several days, they may ulcerate, releasing blood and pus, or cause persistent bleeding, culminating in lower sores. If the body shows signs of intense heat, thirst, and aversion to cold, immediate treatment is required. One should soak with a decoction of soybean and licorice, use a poison-cleansing wash, and take blends like five-spice and honeysuckle decoction for relief. Additionally, one can employ a prescription to manage lower sores and apply soothing ointment to the affected areas, followed by careful post-treatment care. For unquenchable thirst, a decoction of bamboo leaves and astragalus is advised. If the stools are soft, one should take a regulating decoction of poria. By following these treatments, recovery is assured.[47p]

　　　　丹溪心法 【元　朱震亨】

　　　　　疝痛

　　疝痛，湿热痰积流下作病。大概因寒郁而作，即是痰饮食积并死血。　　专主肝经，与肾经绝无相干，大不宜下。　　痛甚者，不宜参、朮。[48p]

Danxi Heart Manual [Yuan Dynasty, Zhu Zhenheng]

Hernial Pain

Hernial pain is caused by damp heat and phlegm accumulation flowing downward. Generally, it occurs due to cold obstruction, resulting in phlegm, food accumulation, and stagnant blood. It primarily concerns the liver channel and has no relation to the kidney channel, thus it is not advisable to treat it with downward methods. In cases of severe pain, ginseng and astragalus are not recommended.[48p]

　　(疒颓)湿多成疝气，宜灸大敦穴，在足大指爪甲后一韭叶聚毛间是穴。　　食积与死血成痛者，栀子、桃仁、山楂、枳子 【一作枳实】 吴茱萸，并炒以生姜汁，顺流水煎汤调服。一方加茴香、附子。　　亦有水气而肿痛者。
　　又有挟虚者，当用参、朮为君，佐以疏导之药。其脉沉紧豁大者是。　　按之不定者，属虚，必用桂枝、山栀炒、乌头细切炒为末，姜汁糊丸，每服三四十丸，姜汤下，大能劫痛。　　按戴思恭云：疝本属厥阴肝之一经。余常见俗说小肠、膀胱下部气者，皆妄言也。
　　　　　木肾

　　木肾者，心火下降则肾水不患其不温，真阳下行则肾气不患其不和，既温且和，安有所谓木强者哉？夫惟嗜欲内戕，肾家虚惫，故阴阳不相交，水火不相济，而沉寒痼冷，凝滞其间，胀大作痛，顽痹结硬，势所必至矣。不可纯用燥热，当温散温利，以逐其邪。邪气内消，荣卫流转，如寒谷回春，盖有不疾而速，不行而至者矣。[49p]

Excessive dampness causes hernias; moxibustion should be applied to the Dadu acupoint, located between the hairs at the base of the toenail of the big toe. For pain caused by food stagnation and dead blood, use gardenia, peach kernels, hawthorn, and bitter orange, along with evodia, all stir-fried with ginger juice, boiled in water, and taken as a decoction. One variation adds fennel and aconite. There are also cases of swelling and pain due to water retention.

For those accompanied by deficiency, ginseng and atractylodes should be the principal ingredients, supported by herbs that promote movement. A deep, tight, and large pulse indicates this. If the pulse is unstable upon palpation, it belongs to deficiency; therefore, it is essential to use a combination of cinnamon twig, fried gardenia, and finely cut and stir-fried aconite, powdered and made into pills with ginger juice. Taking thirty to forty pills followed by ginger broth can significantly alleviate pain. Daisigong stated that hernias fundamentally belong to the Jueyin liver meridian. I often observe that common claims link it to air in the lower parts of the intestine and bladder, which are misconceptions.

The "Wood Kidney" refers to a state where the heart fire descends, allowing the kidney water to remain warm; where the true yang flows down, so kidney energy remains harmonized. When both warm and harmonious, how can there be a strong "Wood"? It is only when excessive desires harm within, causing kidney deficiency and fatigue, that yin and yang fail to interact, and water and fire fail to assist each other. This results in persistent cold, stagnation, swelling, and pain, ultimately leading to stubborn blockage and hardness. It is crucial not to rely solely on dryness and heat; rather, one should warm, disperse, and benefit to expel evil. When the evil qi dissipates internally and the defense and nourishment circulate, it is like the cold valley springing back to life. Indeed, some may recover swiftly without effort, and come to a resolution without movement.[49p]

　　　　　治法

　　凡治七疝，多用热药而获效者，即《内经》从治之法耳。须用寒凉药监制之，不可纯用大热之剂，如乌头、附子之类，令人久服多服，必变剧不可治矣。但宜以二陈汤加枳实、橘核、栀子、山楂等药，煎入生姜汁，热辣饮之。　　恐有瘀血作痛者，本方加延胡索、桃仁泥。　　如有气作痛者，本方加木香、茴香、楝实等药。　　如六脉沉细，手足厥冷者，本方加附子、干姜、肉桂之类以佐之。　　如睾丸痛甚者，加荔枝核、乳香、没药为细末调入。本方煎药内，或另用顺流水调服亦可。　　如木肾肿大如升斗者，本方去甘草加海藻、昆布、荔枝核、茴香、川楝子等药为末，顺流水调服，作丸子服亦可。[50p]

Treatment Method

In treating the seven types of hernias, one often uses warming medicines to achieve efficacy, according to the methods in the "Inner Canon." However, it is necessary to supervise the use of cool and cold medicines and not rely solely on very hot substances like Aconite or Prepared Aconite, as prolonged use can lead to severe, untreatable conditions. Instead, it is advisable to use the Erchen Decoction added with Zhiqiao, Juhua seeds, Gardenia, and Hawthorn, boiled in fresh ginger juice and drunk hot.

If there is pain caused by stagnant blood, add Yanhusuo and crushed peach kernels to this formula. If pain is caused by qi, include Mu Xiang, Fennel, and Melia seeds. If the pulse is deep and thin, and the extremities are cold, add substances like Aconite, Dried Ginger, and Cinnamon to assist.

For severe testicular pain, add Lychee seeds, Frankincense, and Myrrh ground into fine powder and mixed in. This formula can be taken as a decoction or mixed with warm water. If the kidney is swollen to the size of a bowl, remove licorice from the formula and add Seaweed, Kelp, Lychee seeds, Fennel, and Melia seeds, grinding them into powder, which can be taken with warm water or made into pills.[50p]

　　　　　囊痈

　　《外科精要》云：痈疽入囊者死。囊属厥阴，今以死言之，将以为属少阴肾经邪？予亲见入囊者七八人，悉以湿热入肝经施治，而用补阴药佐之，虽脓溃皮脱，睾丸悬挂可畏者，皆不死。但不知下虚年老者如何耳？囊痈，湿热下注也。有作脓者，此浊气润下，将流入渗道，因阴道或亏，水道不利而然。脓尽自安，不药可也。惟在善于调摄耳。又有因腹肿，渐流入囊，肿甚而囊自裂开，睾丸悬挂，水出，以杉木炭末敷外，以紫苏叶包裹，仰卧养之。　　大抵此证属阴道亏，湿热下利所致，故滋阴降湿药不可缺。常治肿痛，小便秘滞者，用除湿为主，滋阴佐之。肿痛已退，便利已和者，除湿滋阴药相兼治之。欲其成脓，用托里为主，滋阴佐之；候脓成即针之，仍用托里滋阴。若湿毒已尽者，专用托里。如脓清或多或敛迟者，用大补之剂，或附子饼灸之。[51p]

Abscess in the Sac

The "Essentials of Surgery" states: If an abscess enters the sac, it leads to death. The sac is associated with the Jue Yin (Liver) pathway; if we interpret "death" in this context, does it imply an evil associated with the Shao Yin (Kidney) channel? I have personally witnessed seven or eight cases where the abscess entered the sac, all of which were treated for damp-heat affecting the Liver channel, supplemented with nourishing Yin herbs. Although pus ruptured and the skin fell off, and while the testicles hung down ominously, none of them died. However, I wonder how it is with the elderly or those with chronic deficiencies? An abscess in the sac indicates damp-heat descending. In cases where there is pus, this signifies that dirty qi is moistening downwards and may flow into the urethra, often due to deficiency of the yin passage or obstruction of the urinary pathway. If the pus is exhausted, it can heal by itself without medicine; it only requires proper regulation.

Additionally, there are instances where abdominal swelling gradually flows into the sac, causing severe swelling until the sac ruptures and fluid drains out. For this, apply powdered cedar charcoal externally and wrap it with perilla leaves, and rest on your back to nurture it. Generally, this condition is due to deficiency of the yin passage and damp-heat leading to discharge, so Yin-nourishing and damp-drying herbs are essential. When treating swelling and pain with urinary retention, prioritize eliminating dampness and supplementing Yin. Once the swelling and pain reduce and urination normalizes, treat with a combination of damp-drying and Yin-nourishing herbs.

If pus is desired, focus on removing pathogens as the main approach while supplementing Yin; once the pus forms, puncture it but continue to use the methods of removing pathogens and nourishing Yin. If the damp-heat is entirely resolved, rely solely on removing pathogens. In cases where the pus is clear or either abundant or slow to resolve, apply strong tonics or moxibustion with aconite cakes.[51p]

　　　　　阴疮

　　男子阴疮，又名耻疮。或痛在茎之窍，或痛在茎之标，皆手足太阳经不利，热毒下传，入于足厥阴经，故变紫黑色，作蚀疮，毁其茎而死。宜以子和泄水丸散导湿毒，无不愈者。若已成疮，先泄其根，次从标而治外。以葱白、黑豆汁渫洗拭干，以黄连、木香、密陀僧、干胭脂之类细末搽之。如内溃脓不出，以追脓散上之，又用子和泄水丸。如后窍脓少，可用黄连、木香、胭脂等贴之。[52p]

Yin Chuang (Genital Ulcer)

In men, Yin Chuang, also known as Chǐ Chuang (shame sore), can cause pain at the tip or the body of the penis. This is due to an imbalance in the Hand and Foot Yang channels, with heat and toxins descending and entering the Foot Jueyin channel, leading to a purple-black coloration, causing ulceration that can destroy the penis and result in death. It is advisable to use Zihe Hexi Shui Wan to dispel dampness and toxins; there are no cases of it not healing. If an ulcer has already formed, first resolve its root, then treat from the exterior. Clean with the juice of scallions and black beans, then apply a fine powder of yellow silk, wood incense, Mita Sang, and dry carmine. If there is internal pus not discharging, use Chui Nang San to push it out, in addition to Zihe Hexi Shui Wan. If there is little pus in the rectum, you may use yellow silk, wood incense, and carmine as a compress.[52p]

　　　　格致余论 【元　朱震亨】

　　　　　疝气论

　　疝气之有甚者，睾丸连小腹急痛也。有痛在睾丸者，有痛在五枢穴边者，皆足厥阴之经也。或有形，或无形，或有声，或无声。有形如瓜，有声如蛙。自《素问》以下，历代名医，皆以为寒。盖寒主收引，经络得寒故收引不行，所以作痛，理固然也。有得寒而无疝者，又必有说以通之可也。予尝屡因门户雪上有霜，没脐之水，踢冰徒涉，不曾病此，以予素无热在内也。因而思之，此证始于湿热在经，郁而至久，又得寒气外束，则湿热之邪，不得疏散，所以作痛。若只作寒论，恐为未备。或曰：厥阴一经，其道远，其位卑，郁积湿热，何由而致？予曰：大劳则火起于心，醉饱则火起于胃，房劳则火起于肾，大怒则火起于肝。本经火积之既久，母能令子虚，湿气便盛。[53p]

On Hernia by Zhu Zhenheng (Yuan Dynasty)

Severe cases of hernia involve acute pain in the testicles and lower abdomen. Pain may be felt in the testicles or near the Wushi acupoint, all of which belong to the Jueyin meridian. There may be physical presence or absence, and sounds can be heard or not. The tangible form resembles a melon, and the sound resembles that of a frog. Since the "Suwen," famous physicians through the ages have attributed this condition to cold. Cold is known to cause constriction; the channels become cold, leading to stagnation and pain. This reasoning is sound. There are instances of cold without hernia, which may also be linked to obstruction.

I have often experienced cold conditions—snow at the door with frost, water below the navel, and stepping on ice—without falling ill, as I traditionally possess no internal heat. Reflecting on this, I believe the condition arises from damp heat in the meridian, accumulating over time, and compounded by cold external influence; thus, the damp heat is unable to disperse and causes pain. If one solely discusses cold, it may be inadequate. Some may argue that the Jueyin meridian is deep and low in position; how can accumulated damp heat occur? I respond: great exertion brings fire to the heart, gluttony or drunkenness ignites fire in the stomach, sexual exhaustion ignites fire in the kidneys, and intense anger ignites fire in the liver. When fire accumulates in this meridian for long periods, it can deplete its mother, causing dampness to prevail.[53p]

厥阴属木，系于肝，为将军之官。其性急速，火性且又暴，今既为寒所束，宜其痛之大暴也。愚见有用乌头、栀子等分作汤用之，其效亦敏捷。后因此方随证与形，加减用之，无有不应。然湿热又须分多少而施治。但湿者肿多，(疒颓)疝是也。又有挟虚而发者，当以参、朮为君，而以疏导药佐之。诊其脉，有甚沉紧而豁大无力者是也。其痛亦轻，惟觉重坠牵引耳。　　下部(疒颓)气不痛之方，细思非痛断房事与厚味不可。若徒恃用药，惟促其寿。若苍朮、神曲、白芷、山楂、川芎、枳实、半夏皆要药。人视其药皆鄙贱之物，以启慢心，又不能断欲以爱护其根本，非徒无益，而反被其害者多矣。且其药宜随时月寒湿，更按君臣佐使加减。大抵(疒颓)疝属湿者多。[54p]

The Jueyin is associated with wood and linked to the liver, serving as the office of the general. Its nature is swift and fiery, yet violent. Now, being constrained by cold, it is no wonder the pain is so severe. In my humble opinion, using aconite and gardenia, prepared as a decoction, may be effective. Following this formula, adjust according to the symptoms and conditions without fail. However, treatment must be divided based on the degree of dampness and heat.

For damp conditions, swelling predominates, which is characteristic of hernias. If there is a combination of deficiency, ginseng and atractylodes should be the main ingredients, supported by guiding herbs. Upon diagnosing the pulse, if it is very deep, tight, but large and without strength, this is indicative. The pain itself is light, merely feeling heavy, pulling, or dragging.

For the lower part when there is no pain, careful consideration shows that abstaining from sexual activity and rich foods is crucial. If one relies solely on medication, they merely shorten their lifespan. Herbs such as white atractylodes, fermented wheat, white angelica, hawthorn, chuanxiong, bitter orange, and pinellia are all necessary. Many tend to regard these herbs as lowly and thereby foster complacency, failing to abandon desires to protect their roots, which is not only unhelpful but often harmful. Additionally, the medication should be adjusted in accordance with the seasonal moisture and cold, following the principles of monarch, minister, and aids. Generally, hernias are more associated with dampness.[54p]

　　　　卫生宝鉴 【元　罗天益】

　　　　　疝

　　至真要大论云：小腹控睾，引腰脊，上冲心，唾出清水，及为白淫，甚则入心，善悲善忘。《甲乙经》曰：邪在小肠也。小肠病者，小腹痛引腰脊，贯肝肺，其经虚不足，则风冷乘间而入。邪气既入则厥，其证上冲肝肺，客冷散于胸，结于脐，控引睾丸，上而不下，痛而入腹，其冲心胸，盖其经络所属所系也。
　　　　　胞痹

　　痹论云：胞痹者，小腹膀胱，按之内痛，若沃以汤，濇于小便，上为清涕。夫膀胱者，为州都之官，津液藏焉，气化则能出矣。今风寒湿邪气客于胞中，则气不能化出，故胞满而水道不通。其证小腹膀胱，按之内痛。若沃以汤，濇于小便，以足太汤经其直行者，上交巅入络脑，下灌鼻窍则清涕也。[55p]

Hygienic Treasure 【Yuan Dynasty, Luo Tianyi】

Hernia

The treatise on the utmost truth states: “The lower abdomen restrains the testicles, affecting the waist and spine, causing a rising sensation to the heart, leading to the expulsion of clear saliva and white fluids, and in severe cases, this sensation may reach the heart, causing sadness and forgetfulness.” The "Classic of Simple and Complex" says: “The pathogen resides in the small intestine.” When suffering from illness in the small intestine, there is pain in the lower abdomen that radiates to the waist and spine, affecting the liver and lungs. If the energy is weak and deficient, then wind-cold can invade. Once the pathogenic energy enters, it manifests as coldness, with symptoms rising to the liver and lungs, causing cold to diffuse in the chest and bind at the navel, pulling on the testicles, rising but unable to descend, causing abdominal pain, affecting the heart and chest, thus correlating with the related meridians.

Bladder Obstruction

The treatise on obstruction states: “Bladder obstruction refers to pain in the lower abdomen and bladder; pressing on it causes pain within, as if doused with soup, leading to discomfort during urination, and resulting in clear mucus discharges.” The bladder is a governmental office for the region, where fluid is stored, and when the energy is transformed, it can be released. Now, if wind, cold, and damp pathogenic energy invade the bladder, then the energy cannot be transformed and released, causing fullness in the bladder and obstruction of the water passage. Symptoms include pain in the lower abdomen and bladder; pressing on it causes pain within. If doused with soup, there is discomfort during urination, with the foot’s Taiyang meridian directly affecting its flow, causing connections to the brain above and draining into the nasal passages below, resulting in clear mucus discharge.[55p]

　　　　医学正传 【明　虞抟】

　　　　　疝气论

　　愚按子和论七疝病源至为详悉，但其处方一以攻下之法为主治，不能使人无疑耳。既曰多由房劳致虚而作，其可一例施之以攻下之法乎？大抵七疝为病，若非房劳所致，即是远行辛苦，涉水履冰，热血得寒，而凝滞于小肠、膀胱之分；或湿热乘虚，而流入于足厥阴之经。古方一以为寒而纯用乌、附等热药为治，我丹溪先生独断为湿热，此发古人之所未发者也。夫热郁于中，而寒束于外，宜其有非常之痛。故治法宜驱逐本经之湿热，消导下焦之痰血，而以寒因热用之法，立方处治，即邪易伏而病易退也。其攻下之法，愚故未敢试而行之，以俟识者。[56p]

On Hernia

I humbly note that Zihe's discussion of the seven sources of hernia disease is quite thorough; however, his prescriptions primarily rely on purgative methods for treatment, which may leave people in doubt. He states that many cases arise from debilitation due to sexual exhaustion, but can one universally apply purgative methods in such instances? Generally speaking, the seven types of hernia, if not caused by sexual exhaustion, may result from long journeys and hardships, crossing waters or walking on ice, which causes hot blood to congeal in the small intestine and bladder; or from damp heat entering the foot's Jueyin meridian. Ancient prescriptions uniformly considered this as cold complaints, solely utilizing warming herbs like Aconite and Fleeceflower for treatment, while my master Danxi independently determined it as damp heat, revealing an insight not previously recognized. When heat is trapped internally and cold binds externally, it is only natural that there would be extraordinary pain. Therefore, the treatment should expel the damp heat from the affected meridian, dissolve phlegm and blood in the lower jiao, and utilize cold to combat heat in a targeted manner, which makes it easier for the pathogen to subside and the illness to retreat. As for the purgative method, I humbly refrain from attempting it without further scholarly insight.[56p]

　　　　明医杂着 【明　王纶】

　　　　　阴痿

　　男子阴痿不起，古方多云命门火衰，精气虚冷，固有之矣。然亦有郁火甚而致痿者。经云：壮火食气。譬如人在暑热而倦怠痿弱，遇冬寒而坚强也。予尝亲见一二人肾经郁火而有此证，令服黄蘗、知母清火坚肾之药而效。故须审察，不可偏认作火衰也。　　 【注　阴茎，属肝之经络。盖肝者木也，如木遇湛露则森立，遇酷热则萎悴。若因肝经湿热而患者，用龙胆泻肝汤以清肝火、导湿热。若因肝经燥热而患者，用六味丸以滋肾水、养肝血而自安。】[57p]

Erectile Dysfunction

In men, erectile dysfunction can arise from a decline in the fire of the life gate and a deficiency of essence and energy. This is an established concept. However, there are also cases where excessive stagnant fire leads to dysfunction. The classics say: "Strong fire consumes energy." This is akin to a person feeling fatigued and weak during the summer heat but becoming strong when winter arrives. I have personally witnessed a few individuals with kidney energy affected by stagnant fire presenting this condition. I recommended they take Huangbo and Zhimu to clear fire and strengthen the kidneys, which was effective. Thus, careful investigation is necessary; it should not be hastily attributed solely to diminished fire.

Note: The penis is associated with the liver's meridian. The liver corresponds to wood; just as wood stands tall when met with gentle dew, it wilts in intense heat. If a patient suffers due to damp heat in the liver channel, one should use Longdan decoction to clear liver fire and dispel damp heat. If the patient suffers from dry heat in the liver channel, one should use Liuwei Dihuang Wan to nourish kidney water and support liver blood for stability.[57p]

　　　　　阴虚疝

　　若阴虚兼有疝气病者，补阴丸加苍朮盐水炒一两半，黄连姜汁炒、山栀炒各六钱，川芎一两，吴茱萸炒、青皮去穰各五钱。　　 【注　疝证专主肝经者多。如运气或在泉寒胜，木气挛缩，禁于此经。或司天燥胜，木气抑郁于此经，或忿怒悲哀，忧抑顿挫，结于此经；或药淋外固，闭尾缩精，壅于此经。其病差别如此。且夫遗溺闭癃，阴痿脬痹，精滑白淫，皆男子之疝也，不可妄归之肾冷。[58p]

Yin Deficiency Hernia

If there is a combination of yin deficiency and hernia disease, one should use Yin Supplement Pills, adding one and a half taels of salt-fried苍术 (Atractylodes macrocephala), six qian each of yellow bitterness and ginger juice, and fried gardenia. One tael of Chuan Xiong (Ligusticum chuanxiong), and five qian each of fried Wu Zhu Yu (Evodia rutaecarpa) and Qing Pi (Citri reticulatae viride pericarpium) should be included.

Note: The symptoms primarily belong to the liver meridian. This may occur when the qi is stagnant or in cases of cold-dampness, leading to contraction in the wood element, restricted in this meridian. It can also arise from excessive dryness which depresses the wood element, or from emotions such as anger and sadness, which hinder the flow in this meridian. Furthermore, herbal treatments that stabilize externally may lead to closure of the orifices, shrinking the essence, and obstructing this meridian. The differences in these conditions should be recognized. Additionally, issues such as incontinence, urinary retention, impotence, and slippery white discharge are all hernias in men and should not be improperly attributed to kidney cold.[58p]

血涸不月，月罢腰膝上热，足躄，嗌干，癃闭，少腹有块，或定或移，前阴突出，后阴痔核，皆女子之疝也，但女子不谓之疝而谓之瘕。若年少而得之，不计男子妇人皆无子。故隐蔽委曲之事，了不干脬、肾、小肠之事，乃足厥阴之证也。窃谓前证若因肝经湿热，当用炒山栀、茯苓、黄蘗、泽泻、川芎、当归、吴茱萸、黄连、山楂。若肝肾二经湿热，当用六味地黄丸料加柴胡、山栀。若肝脾二经阴虚湿热，宜补中益气加炒山栀、炒黑黄连、吴茱萸。盖疝名有七，形证所因不同，治法亦异。】[59p]

When blood is exhausted and not flowing, and there is heat in the waist and knees, with feet feeling numb, throat dry, urinary obstruction, and a mass in the lower abdomen that may be fixed or moving, with the front genitalia protruding and hemorrhoids at the back, these are all manifestations of hernias in women. However, women do not refer to them as hernias but as "jia." If a young person develops these symptoms, neither men nor women will have children. Therefore, these concealed and intricate issues are not related to the bladder, kidneys, or small intestines but rather to the path of the foot's jueyin.

I secretly suggest that if these symptoms arise from damp-heat in the liver channel, one should use stir-fried gardenia, poria, huanglian, and other herbs like dioscorea, angelica, and evodia, along with hawthorn. If there is both liver and kidney damp-heat, use Liuwei Dihuang Wan with additional chaihu and gardenia. If there is damp-heat due to yang deficiency in both the liver and spleen, one should tonify the middle and benefit qi, adding stir-fried gardenia, stir-fried black huanglian, and evodia.

There are seven types of hernias, each with different causes and treatment methods.[59p]

　　　　奇效良方 【明　方贤】

　　　　　囊缩

　　此厥阴经证，其筋脉循阴器，络舌本。厥阴经受病，其筋脉动急，故舌卷囊缩者难治。治用当归四逆汤、吴茱萸生姜汤治之。
　　　　　疝论

　　《巢氏病源》论疝者痛也，其名曰厥、曰症、曰寒、曰盘、曰气、曰附、曰狼，此七者疝之名也。其厥逆心痛足寒，呕吐饮食不下，曰厥疝；腹中气乍满，心下尽痛，气积如臂，曰症疝；因寒饮食，即胁下腹中尽痛，曰寒疝；腹中乍满乍减而痛，曰气疝；腹中痛在脐旁，曰盘疝；腹中脐下有积聚，曰附疝；小腹与阴相引而痛，大便难，曰狼疝。其证发则可验。又有石疝、血疝、阴疝、妒疝、气疝，此五者有名而无形也。外有心疝、寒疝、饥疝、疝癖数者，其名不同，病则大同小异。[60p]

Remarkable Remedies
By Fang Xian (Ming Dynasty)

Constricted Spleen

This relates to the Jueyin channel, where its tendons and vessels flow around the yin organs and connect to the root of the tongue. When the Jueyin channel suffers from illness, its tendons and vessels become reactive, hence a rolled and constricted tongue is difficult to treat. For treatment, use the Decoction of Dong Quai and Four Extreme Herbs, and the Ginger and Wuzhuyu Decoction.

Discussion on Hernia

The "Cao's Source of Diseases" discusses hernias as painful conditions, referred to by names such as Jue, Zheng, Han, Pan, Qi, Fu, and Lang. These seven names correspond to types of hernias. Jue hernia manifests with cold feet and heart pain, accompanied by vomiting and inability to eat, while Zheng hernia presents with sudden abdominal distension and severe pain beneath the heart, causing gas buildup similar to an arm. A hernia due to cold dietary intake leads to pain in the lower abdomen, termed Han hernia. Qi hernia features intermittent abdominal fullness and pain, while Pan hernia has pain next to the navel. Fu hernia involves accumulation below the navel, and Lang hernia is characterized by pain in the lower abdomen radiating to the genital area, along with difficulty in defecation. Symptoms can be verified upon manifestation. Moreover, there are stone hernias, blood hernias, yin hernias, jealous hernias, and qi hernias—these five have names but lack forms.Externally, there are heart hernias, cold hernias, hunger hernias, and multiple types of hernias, which have different names but share similar illnesses.[60p]

世俗呼为小肠气、膀胱气、奔豚气、蟠肠气、横弦、竖弦、偏坠、木肾、肾余、阴肿与疝病，其名有别也。至于张子和论七疝，曰寒疝、水疝、筋疝、血疝、狐疝、气疝、(疒颓)疝之名，又与诸论不同。且如(疒颓)疝者，外肾坚肿也。痛者为阴肿，不痛者为木肾，一边坠下者为偏坠。疝诸论立名虽多且异。《灵枢经》云：邪在小肠，连睾系属肾，贯肝络肺系心。气盛，厥气上冲也。《内经》又云：任脉为病，男子内结七疝，女子带下瘕聚。冲脉逆为气里急。然则任脉虽称病有七疝之名，而无七疝之状。而任脉者，是疝病之本源，各经是病疝之支流也。[61p]

In popular usage, these are referred to as "small intestine qi," "bladder qi," "running pig qi," "twisted intestine qi," "horizontal string," "vertical string," "lateral droop," "wood kidney," "kidney remnants," "yin swelling," and "hernia," each with distinct names. As for Zhang Zihe’s discussion of the seven hernias, he mentions "cold hernia," "water hernia," "muscle hernia," "blood hernia," "fox hernia," "qi hernia," and "tuǐ hernia," which differ from other discussions. For example, the "tuǐ hernia" refers to a hard swelling of the outer kidney. If it is painful, it is called "yin swelling"; if not painful, it is "wood kidney"; if it droops on one side, it is "lateral droop." Although there are many different names and classifications for hernias, the Ling Shu says: the pathogen resides in the small intestine, linking to the testicles and associated with the kidney, and connects to the liver and affects the heart. When the qi is abundant, it causes counterflow of the qi upwards. The Nei Jing further states: when the Ren vessel is affected, men present with seven internal hernias, while women experience discharge and masses. When the Chong vessel is reversed, it leads to urgent qi. Therefore, while the Ren vessel is called a source of disease with the name of seven hernias, it does not manifest the forms of the seven hernias. The Ren vessel is the foundational source of hernia diseases, while the other meridians represent the tributaries of hernia afflictions.[61p]

又云：厥阴脉滑为狐疝，少阳脉滑为肝风疝，太阴脉滑为脾风疝，少阴脉滑为心风疝，太阳脉滑为肾风疝，阳明脉滑为肺风疝。此风非外入之风，乃肝木阳脏气动之风也。此六疝者，应乎六经，在于五脏。何谓疝病皆属肝？病生于阴，起于下，阴者内之，太阴脾、厥阴肝、少阴肾，皆足之阴经也。下者地下寒气也，足常履地，盖天地之风寒，皆入于地，人之风湿皆从足起。或因经虚，聚于脬囊小腹，两阴相并，二气相搏，则为疼痛矣。或冷饮过情，水流归肾，或坐卧处湿，寒搏留阴，以寒攻阴则为疝痛。经曰：痛者，通也。疝气作痛，宜通不宜塞，宜温不宜凉。通谓泻其实，不泻其虚。寒谓补其虚，不补其实。[62p]
